content:
9, 2016
												I wanted to like this game. I really did. When I first played it, it had the look of Final Fantasy XII (that's the latest game in the series I have played so that's why it's my comparison point) and a fairly good story to match. The combat system at first was appealing. It was different, which I liked. However, as the story progressed and I went further into the game, I started to stop liking it and started to loathe it... and loathe it... and loathe it.The problems I have with this game are as follows:1) The combat system. You don't get to fully choose what your unions can do in each turn. You only get to choose from up to five options that the RNG decides what you can choose between (one of which is always the basic attack option). Each set of options changes for each opposing union you can engage so there's a lack of consistency. This means that you will often find situations where you want to heal your units or choose to defend, but only be given the option to attack. When you're being sent into battle against an enemy you know is too strong, you're more than likely going to quit before you get killed.How they could have done it: Have a standard set of options available to each union for each opposing union. Standard attack, physical arts, mystic arts, healing arts, defend. Additional options can be added in for relevant opponents or scenarios, such as closing in on distant enemies, using item arts or initiating unique attacks such as Omnistrike or the Gae Bolg. Make it consistent and take away the RNG element that makes the system unreliable.2) The item system. This is just a catastrophic failure in my opinion. It's overly complicated and to this day I still don't understand half of it. My first problem is why can't you change the equipment of any member of your party except Rush? SERIOUSLY! What the hell, Square? Every other game you've done like this allows you to change the gear of other members of your party. Were you trying so hard to not make another Final Fantasy game that you decided none of them needed equipment changes unless the characters just so happen to ask for it? Once again, you put the player at the mercy of the RNG in a part of the game that shouldn't even be random! Also, why did you feel the need to have every member of Rush's group constantly ask for random items? Why did you have to make the system for giving them better equipment overly complicated? It's unwarranted and infuriating, especially since half of the weapons available from the merchants throughout the game have to be given to other members of the party... but only if they randomly happen to ask for it after you've bought it.My next problem about the item system relates to the method for upgrading and building weapons and accessories. Why did it have to be so complicated and also not even necessary to proceed with the story? I have not ONCE upgraded any of my weapons nor have I ever created anything new. Reason being, I have never been fortunate enough to possess the very precise consumables needed to do so. Yet, I never felt the need to try to obtain them because the game already provides you with effective pieces of equipment for completing quests or even just exploring areas and finding chests. You added a feature that was confusing and complicated... and then made it completely unnecessary. So my inventory was full of tons of rare enemy drops that I didn't want to sell because I felt I might need them... for no real reason at all.How they could have done it: Make it possible to change the equipment of your other party members just like in every other game you've made. If you want to have a weapon crafting system, reduce the requirements for creating them and make the item drops rarer and reduce the numbers of items you can obtain. Also, remove the constant nagging requests from every one of your party members asking for items you've never even heard of. It's pointless and wastes time whenever you go to a city map.3) The Battle Rank system (including quests). Now this has been the one problem I've encountered most in this game. Many of the walkthroughs and forums online say to keep your battle rank as low as possible and to avoid battles as much as you can and then others say to grind and get it nice and high. Honestly, it's overly confusing and I've found that if you don't engage in battles, you get slaughtered. But it's not just ordinary grinding you have to do. It's the quests. Quests in RPGs are necessary for a simple reason. They provide a source of money, items, allies, experience etc. However, they are OPTIONAL, except in this game. In The Last Remnant, if you don't complete the quests, you will be killed when you get to a boss fight. Why that is, I cannot say. I do however know that it's true. I failed to beat many bosses, so I went away to take on some quests, did as many as I could handle before I got bored, went back to the boss and beat them (after a smaller number of attempts). Not only this, but you are encouraged to take on the quests before a certain point in the game because if you don't, you lose the opportunity to do all of the quests you left behind and any areas you didn't unlock before that point will be lost for the rest of the game. I consider this to be a massive mistake on Square's part. In Final Fantasy VII, you had to change the discs, but you still had access to most of the elements in the game when you changed them. You only lost the chance to unlock a small number of secrets, but the majority of the game was still available to you. So why did they make The Last Remnant in such a different and quite frankly, horrible way? I don't want to feel pressured to complete what I feel are a bunch of tedious and boring quests just to make sure I can progress in the game, especially since all of the quests I have found follow the same format (except one). Get transported to location. traverse location to find boss. Defeat boss. Claim reward. It gets even more boring because of the fact that you keep running into groups of enemies that will run after you and force you to battle if you can't get away.I'm going off on a tangent here so I'm going to just end this section.How they could have done it: Make quests optional and replace the battle rank system with an ordinary level system that applies to each individual party member (which would make it easier to form even unions with in my opinion). Also, don't revoke access to areas within the game just because you've reached the middle of the game's story, In addition to that, add in different kinds of quests. They don't all have to end in a boss battle. They can be simpler such as delivering items from one area to another. The quests in Final Fantasy XII were varied enough. Why not here?4) Battle length. This is one of the reasons quests drag on so much. The battles take so long. The animations are not skippable and you have to watch the entire thing even though you're not doing anything yourself.How they could have done it: Add an option to skip battle animations and just give the player the outcome of each engagement. Simple.There are other gripes I have with the way the game was made but I'm going to leave it there for the simple reason that it's long enough already and I doubt that most of you will have even read the entire review. If you did read it all, go have a cookie. You deserve it.The fact of the matter is, I expected a lot more from Square Enix. They're an incredible group and have produced games for one of the most famous RPG titles for years. Yet, The Last Remnant just fails to live up to the name. Had it not been for the way the world was designed and the unique races that you find in the game, I would never have been able to guess it was a Square Enix title if they took their name off of it. I only managed to make it to the Gates of Hell before I just couldn't take it anymore. GG Square. You beat me.

												This game is amazing. I would recommend using a controller, I personally use an Xbox one controller. This game is deep, you can fly through this game and get a pretty good story. For first time players, this game can be complicated and frustrating. You have to plan how you want to build your characters. I'm on my 1st playthrough on PC. I have 4 other playthroughs on Xbox. I still haven't played with all the different skill types.Great game!

												Do you like the Final Fantasy franchise and are you are also looking for a new and interesting storyline? Then this is the game for you!!! This has an awesome turn based battle system. Even though the graphics are not equivalent to Crysis 3 it is still very enjoyable. Keep in mind that this game was released in 2009 so please don't be ♥♥♥ and say "THe GrApHiqs aRen't l1ke BaTlLeFiElD! ". This game also has a morale system that takes place when you enter a battle phase. There are also other factors that can turn the battle around at any point such as the Multi Deadlock, the Flank Attack, and the Rear Assault, and etc. Overall this game was great considering that it was released in 2009. I would give it a 9/10 on gamplay, 8/10 on story, 9.5/10 on the combat system, and 9/10 overall. This is all great and everything, but the question that you might be asking yourself is "But how much does it cost?" The truth is, it only costs $12.99! So take your kids' lunch money and buy this game!

content:
9, 2016
												I wanted to like this game. I really did. When I first played it, it had the look of Final Fantasy XII (that's the latest game in the series I have played so that's why it's my comparison point) and a fairly good story to match. The combat system at first was appealing. It was different, which I liked. However, as the story progressed and I went further into the game, I started to stop liking it and started to loathe it... and loathe it... and loathe it.The problems I have with this game are as follows:1) The combat system. You don't get to fully choose what your unions can do in each turn. You only get to choose from up to five options that the RNG decides what you can choose between (one of which is always the basic attack option). Each set of options changes for each opposing union you can engage so there's a lack of consistency. This means that you will often find situations where you want to heal your units or choose to defend, but only be given the option to attack. When you're being sent into battle against an enemy you know is too strong, you're more than likely going to quit before you get killed.How they could have done it: Have a standard set of options available to each union for each opposing union. Standard attack, physical arts, mystic arts, healing arts, defend. Additional options can be added in for relevant opponents or scenarios, such as closing in on distant enemies, using item arts or initiating unique attacks such as Omnistrike or the Gae Bolg. Make it consistent and take away the RNG element that makes the system unreliable.2) The item system. This is just a catastrophic failure in my opinion. It's overly complicated and to this day I still don't understand half of it. My first problem is why can't you change the equipment of any member of your party except Rush? SERIOUSLY! What the hell, Square? Every other game you've done like this allows you to change the gear of other members of your party. Were you trying so hard to not make another Final Fantasy game that you decided none of them needed equipment changes unless the characters just so happen to ask for it? Once again, you put the player at the mercy of the RNG in a part of the game that shouldn't even be random! Also, why did you feel the need to have every member of Rush's group constantly ask for random items? Why did you have to make the system for giving them better equipment overly complicated? It's unwarranted and infuriating, especially since half of the weapons available from the merchants throughout the game have to be given to other members of the party... but only if they randomly happen to ask for it after you've bought it.My next problem about the item system relates to the method for upgrading and building weapons and accessories. Why did it have to be so complicated and also not even necessary to proceed with the story? I have not ONCE upgraded any of my weapons nor have I ever created anything new. Reason being, I have never been fortunate enough to possess the very precise consumables needed to do so. Yet, I never felt the need to try to obtain them because the game already provides you with effective pieces of equipment for completing quests or even just exploring areas and finding chests. You added a feature that was confusing and complicated... and then made it completely unnecessary. So my inventory was full of tons of rare enemy drops that I didn't want to sell because I felt I might need them... for no real reason at all.How they could have done it: Make it possible to change the equipment of your other party members just like in every other game you've made. If you want to have a weapon crafting system, reduce the requirements for creating them and make the item drops rarer and reduce the numbers of items you can obtain. Also, remove the constant nagging requests from every one of your party members asking for items you've never even heard of. It's pointless and wastes time whenever you go to a city map.3) The Battle Rank system (including quests). Now this has been the one problem I've encountered most in this game. Many of the walkthroughs and forums online say to keep your battle rank as low as possible and to avoid battles as much as you can and then others say to grind and get it nice and high. Honestly, it's overly confusing and I've found that if you don't engage in battles, you get slaughtered. But it's not just ordinary grinding you have to do. It's the quests. Quests in RPGs are necessary for a simple reason. They provide a source of money, items, allies, experience etc. However, they are OPTIONAL, except in this game. In The Last Remnant, if you don't complete the quests, you will be killed when you get to a boss fight. Why that is, I cannot say. I do however know that it's true. I failed to beat many bosses, so I went away to take on some quests, did as many as I could handle before I got bored, went back to the boss and beat them (after a smaller number of attempts). Not only this, but you are encouraged to take on the quests before a certain point in the game because if you don't, you lose the opportunity to do all of the quests you left behind and any areas you didn't unlock before that point will be lost for the rest of the game. I consider this to be a massive mistake on Square's part. In Final Fantasy VII, you had to change the discs, but you still had access to most of the elements in the game when you changed them. You only lost the chance to unlock a small number of secrets, but the majority of the game was still available to you. So why did they make The Last Remnant in such a different and quite frankly, horrible way? I don't want to feel pressured to complete what I feel are a bunch of tedious and boring quests just to make sure I can progress in the game, especially since all of the quests I have found follow the same format (except one). Get transported to location. traverse location to find boss. Defeat boss. Claim reward. It gets even more boring because of the fact that you keep running into groups of enemies that will run after you and force you to battle if you can't get away.I'm going off on a tangent here so I'm going to just end this section.How they could have done it: Make quests optional and replace the battle rank system with an ordinary level system that applies to each individual party member (which would make it easier to form even unions with in my opinion). Also, don't revoke access to areas within the game just because you've reached the middle of the game's story, In addition to that, add in different kinds of quests. They don't all have to end in a boss battle. They can be simpler such as delivering items from one area to another. The quests in Final Fantasy XII were varied enough. Why not here?4) Battle length. This is one of the reasons quests drag on so much. The battles take so long. The animations are not skippable and you have to watch the entire thing even though you're not doing anything yourself.How they could have done it: Add an option to skip battle animations and just give the player the outcome of each engagement. Simple.There are other gripes I have with the way the game was made but I'm going to leave it there for the simple reason that it's long enough already and I doubt that most of you will have even read the entire review. If you did read it all, go have a cookie. You deserve it.The fact of the matter is, I expected a lot more from Square Enix. content:
er 17, 2015
												Quite a nice JRPG from Square that isn't a Final Fantasy. Pros:Above average JRPG graphics. Don't expect photorealism however. Some spells and abilities have great visuals though and same goes for invocations.The combat system and the way strategy is designed make for some nice gameplay.Unique characters, some of which with backstory to discover in side quests.The main quest is long enough without being necesseraly tedious.Unique cities, very varied to visit.Con: Character levelling is difficult to grasp since it's dependant entirely on the arts and abilities used in game, which are linked to the chosen weapon, with no real ingame help how to tailor and fine tune it. Player effect on character stats is indirect through equipment solely.It's a JRPG so it's somewhat on railroads and definitely not an open world like Fallout or Skyrim. A lot more freedom of movement and action in this one than in many other JRPG but it's restrained at times.If you follow the story, the ending is really expected. So the main story could definitely be improved.I've overall spent a nice time roaming the various, very unique cities, all of them with a specific style and going through sidequests, not of a few of which are very humorous. The way combat is done may rebuke some, but it's got its advantages although it can be quite frustrating at times. I prefer to have more control on my characters in general, but that was far from an obstacle. Crafting offers some variety though looking for specific components can take some time. Recruiting unique squad leaders and unique/rare bosses make free exploration rewarding.It's not the game of the century but definitely worth the investment to have a relaxed time in a JRPG by Square Enix. These guys know to make games.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
er 28, 2013
												!!! THE LAST REMNANT !!!Comming From the Xbox 360 Version, this game has undone some extreame polish for PC since it's release. i've endured the major issues with the console version of this game from start to finish, and have recently moved to the PC version because of it's much needed updates.This is an outstanding game. Using the best of SAGA character development, an innovative combat engine modeled off of squad tactics, but with each character being individualy accounted for (if they are the one attacked, thier chance to dodge is what matters, but formations and current tactics effect who is at risk) an intruiging and well told plot (note, "side" quest are essential to experience the majority of it), outstanding graphics (as played on a PC), and most of all, constantly fun. There is something of a steep curve to get good at combat, and if you do not wrap your mind around it, it may seem random, but it isn't very random at all, and a keen understanding of pre fighting tactical choices (setup) and in combat tactical choices is essential to beat any of the major monsters from about the first 1/5 of the game on. fortunately there are numerious (really unlimited) fights with lesser monsters, and so equally limited (or not) chances to experament. Worth playing by all rpg fans, this manages to be unique and present some experamental ideas with polish and mechanical balance that makes it seem like a much more mature project. on a side note, many reviewers were turned off by the combat engine. I suspect this came from not indulging enough in the gameplay, it is not a standard console rpg, mechanically, and one should not expect to succeed without some new ways of thinking. That said, it is something that the rpg (jrpg especially) market really needs. LR's combat engine is also important as a story telling device, because it is not the story of a few super heroes, but rather of a world war, and the player controls an army. The combat engine allows the player to quickly, elligantly, with simple menu choices and just a few buttons, control a small army of 36 unit (6-10 squads if mem serves), and fight even larger ones, as well as fascilitates massive bosses attacked by your army. For instance, your army fighting a dragon and its horde of followers, in one large battle. So far, no J-styled rpg has greatly surpased the techniques used in the earliest FF games, a big fight as described above would just be your 1 squad fighting a series of battles without a break, followed finally by the big bad, and *maybe* letting you fight the big bad with more than one squad. Games which have used engines to deliver more, have been too convoluted for simple menu based play. LR manages to be simple to control, fun to think about (as a tactical puzzle, which is the big draw of JRPG combat) and delivers a constantly rewarding and enthralling experience.In spite of a few small flaws, LR remains a well designed and built game, consnstantly fun and hcallenging, and truly innovative and worth the time of any player looking for a brilliant new idea-XeroSyphon

content:
ry 16, 2014
												I was looking for some good RPGs a few weeks ago and I saw someone recommending this game. When I looked at it on Steam I wasn't really sure about buying it... Well, I did and now I must say that you MUST buy it!!!The Last Remnant is an awesome Strategy / RPG game!The combat system feels good, making it easy, but also very challenging at some points. It focus a lot on group combat, while you can't choose each character's action, you can order the group to do the same thing in a strategic way. You can split your party members into units that can have up to 5 members, when you choose an action, the whole unit will perform that same action. The game sometimes changes the options you have in battle, for example, if you're in a story related battle, it sometimes changes your combat options, making you trigger an event. The strategy you use is totally up to you to decide, the game gives you a lot of customizable options, you can change an unit's formation, change it's members, and use specific commands in battle, like ordering an unit to heal other unit.The graphics are also very good, you know, for a 2009 game.. And since it's a Square Enix game, you can expect a lot of amazing cutscenes and a very well written fantasy story. There's also a few more features included, like crafting and hiring soldiers to your party.The game only lacks in some things, like the character's level, since there's no level thingy, sometimes when you complete a battle, your characters can get stronger, gaining HP, AP, Attack, and even their weapons can get improved, but you can't see your stats growth 100%, you can only see things like the HP getting bigger. The option to choose each character's equipment would also be very usefull!So, I would trully recommend this game to anyone who likes JRPGs! The game is also very cheap!!8.5/10

content:
19, 2011
												You play as Rush Sykes , a young man who is on a quest to find his kidnapped sister. He later runs into a group of people who are willing to aid in him in is journey. Things turn for the worse when a war breaks out  over control of ancient atrifacts known as remnants, and finding the sister seems impossible. The gameplay in the game is fantastic. At times it can be very overwhelming and seem impossible to figure it out at times,  mainly becasue you do not control one person but groups, or unions, but trust me when I say it is possible to master it. If you are new to JRPG's I would not recommend you getting this title just yet. If you are comfortible around JRPG's and want a challenge then by all means purchase this game immediatly. This game requires patience as well as skill  because this is a 50+ hour game and like I said the battles can take some time to get used to. If you are looking for a challenge and just enjoy a very good story then I highly recommend you buy this game.

content:
er 25, 2013
												If you liked Final Fantasy 12, you'll probably like this game. It uses pretty much the same game engine as FF12, though the combat in this game is turn-based and more complex, and it incorporates team confrontations that are larger in scale than those in FF12. The look, style, and setting of the two games, while not the same, are very similar. However, this game could never run on a PS2. It has widescreen graphics with high-resolution textures, advanced lighting and shadows, and higher polygon counts than a PS2 could handle.Even though this game runs great on a PC, it's not meant to be played with a keyboard & mouse, which results in confusion and frustration. Use instead a gamepad, preferably an Xbox-compatible one, with similar button layout and colors.The Logitech ones (which are Xbox-compatible) work pretty good.

content:
2, 2014
												Ok, I got this game as a gift from my girlfriend.I really had a lot of expectations, and added it to my wishlist after having watched a trailer and played a demo on the Xbox 360.Well... after around 35 hours I started wondering how come enemies were becoming stronger and stronger (e.g. 1 hit kill) even though I had good strategy. Let's break the issues down:- Fighting/Turn based whatever: this is pretty much random. You can attack an enemy, but even though it's your turn sometimes enemies get more turns than you do, and even take your turn! As soon as you reach a level of 25+ and progress through the storyline, then this becomes a problem since you get your a** kicked REALLY badly.- Grinding: I wandered around a lot in this game, trying to get more XP in order to unlock some magic, special skill, new areas, collectables, and so on, as it is in any RPG. For example, exploring areas around you and encountering enemies it's always for the sake of a good battle but.... as you read in my first point, I soon realised that this game is not meant for exploration because exploration means fighting (of course, you meet enemies and even if you try to avoid them, you'll probable end up in bloody mess with attacks from everywhere), and it's not about the classic role playing gaming you are used to. This game does not want you to explore or fight - which is the main thing about RPGs - , else you end up with a really high level and you are f***ed as every fight will be a disaster and you'll probably end up using a trainer in order to just finish the game and just delete it forever. Ok, you might say that there is a challenge, however there isn't hardly a challenge here; the game is unfair at all levels, the AI will be just concatenating attacks even if it's your turn, and if you want to have great weapons and "hoping" to kick some enemies' a**es , well you can only get those by collecting materials (killing enemies?) and exploring, and then? Ha! Well, then the enemies will level up as well, so it's just a pointless chain.If you have time to spend, have patience to spend months and months on this game just to reach an ending to a story that is not really that great tbh, and if you don't like classic RPGs, then go ahead. I strongly suggest not to play this game if you don't want to end up hating RPGs.I think I should go back and play some good old Skies of Arcadia.I'm so glad I completed this game, finally.

												This game recommend when its on sale but for full retail of  $10 its not bad priced either had over 90 hours of game play for me. Rush the main character is on  a mission to find is little sister kidnapped by the conqueror the main enemy.  If you play the story straight through and no side quest/missions you can probably beat the game in or under 25-30 hours.  Graphics similar to the final fantasy series since it was produced by square enix. If you see this game at 50% or 75% off well worth the buy.

y 1, 2015
												This is a difficult choice, the game has a lovely new and unique battle system that is fun to use and can be customised in great depth. However the story is rather slow and many times I saw myself taking long breaks (weeks or months) away from the game so I could enjoy it.Another problem is that you have almost no control over a characters growth, it is eaither too easy or too hard, you will be able to swep through areas without much effort, or you will be forced to fight opponents one at a time (which takes ages).I believe the game is very well made, the story is fresh and new, and very nice to look at.However the game failed to keep hold of me and therefore I have chosen not to reccomend this game unless you are willing to be very patient.

number of helpful: 27 of 50 people (54%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ry 18, 2015
												I am now going to write some things about a video game.This video game is called "The Last Remnant." Like many Japanese RPGs, the MC is a young child (called Rush) who is  estranged from his parents, and naturally this is a key plot point and one of the driving forces behind the story. This is generic and loathsome and not something I enjoy. However, the detestable MC, who is probably named after his tendencies to act brashly and without thought (Very subtle, game.) is one of the few characters I found myself disliking. I rather quickly grew fond of David and his 4 generals, for instance, despite their lack of any given motive other than to serve their leader. In fact, David's motives are perhaps the most confusing of all. I found myself playing on to try and discover what they were.However, along the way, I was swept away by my love for the combat. It's highly detailed and strategy based; you create squads of soldiers and have them perform commands as a group. It's an interesting style and quickly captured my attention. However, it quickly lost it again once I realised how grindy the game is. It's also needlessly complex for newer players, not teaching anything more than "Attack enemies! Heal allies! Win fights! Don't lose!" The character progression system is overly complex, and is never quite explained, to my knowledge. I've done a fair bit of research, and the gist of it is that the more a unit uses a specific type of command, the better it becomes with that type of command (e.g magic, physical attacks, healing spells) and will learn more powerful abilities of that type. However, managing the equipment of your allies is hopelessly complex and grindy and this is where the game falls down. It's painfully slow in the early to mid game, and that's about as far as I got before getting bored and giving up.It pains me to say that I don't recommend the game. It's an interesting game with a fairly nice range of characters, and there is some kind of ridiculously complex yet... existing plot. It features magic, so you know it's good. But the monotony, repetitive battles and grindy nature make it far too slow to enjoy. And this is coming from a guy who loves a good grind.

content:
, 2013
												If you are looking for a very deep RPG that has tons of polish, The Last Remnant is very satisfying. You may hear complaints about the lack of control during battles, but I see it as a nifty time saver. Instead of telling each member of each party what monster to attack and what to use, you tell the whole party instead to just use magic, or physical, or heal, or just stay out of the battle in case you want to level the other parties abilities. I have 150 hours on record and still havent beaten this game, there is so much hidden in this game. You will need to read some guids to get the most out of this game, but you can also just play casually and enjoy the engrossing story and amazingly artistic cities and landscapes. Really, it is amazing how detailed this world and its lore is.

content:
y 17
												before you read this seemingly negative review, keep in mind that i still recommend the game because i think it is overall great.oh and here's an obligatory "sorry for broken english, me no native, or any good at it"now, this game is not perfect, it's actually very flawed in many ways, some consolitis sympthoms and a bit of general oddities among other things. for starters, the way it handles your party and their inventory is just plain stupid. it's not game breaking but it can be rather inconvenient. what i'm refering to here is the fact that your party will ask you for resources they need, but will be unable to grab said resources from your inventory, and you also cant give it to them. you have to go find it after receiving the request. this game also relies heavily on Wiki crawling, otherwise you may just miss half the game.it's a hard game, expect grinding. not just simple "find things and kill them" grinding either, theres techniques and methods that will gain you the best results, grinding simply through finding things and killing them can be directly counter productive. there are also good characters that arent explored at all or just far too little, leaving you wishing there was a place to find more trivia about their pasts or personalities. there are also technical issues here and there. i personally had a couple crashes and memory leaks, plus shadows that are glitchy on AMD Graphics cards. i also recommend that this be played with a controller of some description, i found it to just generally work better. you can play with keyboard and mouse too, just remember to go into the options and tell the game to show you the prompts properly.but with all those issues, even plus some, i still say this game is well worth its price. i ended up more or less binging the damn thing. the story is engaging and the characters are likable. the universe is facinating and the visuals, while not very high fidelity, still manages to pull off sceneries that at times are far more impressive and imaginative than most fantasy games these days, save maybe from final fantasy. the gameplay is also an interesting part of this game. it remains turn based like most jRPGs, but it relies a lot on strategy and to varying degree also luck. i found it fun and engaging in large battles, though grinding gets bothersome fast. i would glardly suggest you pick up this game if you see it on a sale, and if it's already in your library from who knows where, install it and try it. you might just like it.

content:
3, 2013
												The Last Remnant is a pretty darn fun game of its type. it's solid enough to be worth your time if you've taken the time to read this.I really enjoyed this. As a bakka gaijn I've always found many  jrpg story aspects to come across a bit stunted or less than natural, and this game is generally the same, at least when the characters get into long conversations and try to be super dramatic with their fifteen second pauses between sentences. The story itself is standard stuff, but done well enough to keep you from getting bored. I found the combat to be really a high point of this. It's pretty damn strategic. You HAVE to spend ten or so minutes reading a combat guide describing how everything works, though, if you're going to have any chance of understanding and enjoying it. The group controls are determined by the specific characters (and their focused skills) in each group and is also influenced by their location on the battlefield -  relative to the enemies. it's interesting, and never feels repetitive. You can recruit many different people, kinda like Suikoden, and train them up in different ways, each with their own different bit of story to contribute and it's pretty cool. There's crafting to make weapons and gear and potions and stuff. I thought it was a really pretty game with some cool combat systems and a lot of different quests and people and things to talk to. This game discourages grinding and over leveling, so be careful not to. If you just play it, you'll be fine.

content:
ry 8, 2015
												To read other reviews this port is much easier than the original console version. That must have been something because I am still getting my ♥♥♥ kicked just a few hours in at the first serious boss battle. Don't think I'm doing anything obviously wrong either. Given that the game isn't even entirely out of tutorial mode at this point, one might expect a little less of a steep learning curve. As it is, the fun has largely been drained out of it. Some may like it.That aside, the game is reasonably pretty. The characters display the usual array of JRPG expressions and personae, which can be an acquired taste. But the dialogue, especially in the english dub I suspect, does not flow at all. Long silences between each line, as if the game was loading a new tape each time. That makes it hard to feel engaged in whatever they are saying.Therefore overall: decent interface, irritating gameplay difficulty, and forgettable / mildly annoying story development: I'll give this game a pass after all.

And the whole dungeon was empty basically, with a few enemies here and there. - The world map is ugly, feels amaturish.- the towns are static, and the maps are tiny. I suppose the team had limitation back than fighting the xbox memory.- It is the same old JRPG thing that there are a few civilians standing there with a excalamation mark on the top of there had and repeating the same 2 lines again and again, it was already dumb in 2005, not 2010 or nowadays.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 9, 2014
												I have to say this is one of my favorite RPGs; with dozens of characters each with their own background and often related sidequests, a unique story and battle system, and excellent graphics and voice acting, it is easy to find things worth recommending. Completing all there is to do in the game would easily take you over 100 hours, but the cool thing is you can spend as much or as little time as you want delving into the side missions, crafting, and rare monster hunts or focusing on the story. New Game + gives some good replay value, especially coupled with the amount there is to do in the game. You are also able to choose the combat focus not only of the main character, but all the characters who each have a variety of abilities for you to decide which to utilize and improve. Use awesome weapon techniques or cast powerful magics from a wide variety of schools, all the while improving your stats and abilities based on what you choose to use.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
y 9, 2015
												TL;DR -- Story saves the game from the furnace, but everything else assures it stays in the bargain bin. 4/10I've tried twice now to like this game. The first was years ago on my Xbox, and now on the PC. The story is appealing and involved, but the main character is a cringeworthy blockhead. I understand at the beginning of the game he's meant to be lovably obtuse; a character meant to have room to grow. But it'll leave you gnashing your teeth at his sheer density more often than not.Additionally, the game's scaled-down version of Dynasty Warriors it calls a battle system is a hot mess touted as being unique. There are so many things going on at once you're left guessing who's attacking what at any given time. You are encouraged to attack multiple enemies at once due to additional reward drops, but this can be unfair at times. If an NPC-controlled unit contends a player-controlled one, the enemy NPCs usually get a first swing, and rightly so. But I have found, much to my dismay/frustration, that this is STILL the norm even when a player-controlled unit starts a skirmish. Enemies will get to attack you first whether you're on offense/defense, and it has bequeathed me with a Game Over more times than I can count. And if ever you wish to heal your units, you have to break off fighting any enemy units you're currently skirmishing. And you know what that does? You guessed it; it provides the enemy with another chance to attack you.The game also suffers from an error many of its predecessors have made: level-scaled enemies. No matter how strong your characters get, you're no stronger comparitively to NPCs than you were at level 1. You just dish out bigger numbers against bigger health pools.Worse still, if you don't have a character in your party, they will not receive XP. Couple this with scaled enemies, and you will have a very, VERY tough time trying to level-up any neglected party members later in the game.Another minor nit-pick is that the camera controls while using a keyboard do not lock while navigating dialogue or game menus. You will often see the camera pan/jitter while moving up/down/left/right through menu screens, and yes this does happen during battle as well. Again, minor annoyance, but it is pervasive, and for this reason I had to complete the game on my Xbox instead (notice the 1.5 game hours on record).I feel this game's story was a solid pitch, but then poor dialogue and (english) acting, as well as an experimental battle system gone awry have left it collecting dust. It's unfortunate, considering an epic story is only 1/3 of the formula that makes this genre great--the other 2/3 being story delivery and battle system, where this game falls horribly short.Can't a guy dream for the return of the original turn-based encounter system? Tried and true, it's what put this genre on its feet. What on earth was so wrong with it? Don't fix something that isn't broken.11.9GB of squandered potential.

content:
er 26, 2013
												One of those games that no one has heard of. Made by Square Enix, The Last Remnant is a unique J-RPG and is probably the most underrated and unappreciated game I have ever played.There are many forums, faq sites, and even an entire wiki dedicated to the game, so I'm not the only one who loved it.Amazing gameplay with hundreds of characters to choose from to form your army.The battle system is also very unique; has a squad based battle system with squads (unions) formed using characters you have recruited / allied with.It might seem unneccesarily convoluted at first, but you will see things fall into place as your party and unions expand. You can spend ages just tweaking formations, party combinations and arts.Characters have a massive range of skills too, some will be amazing warriors - evading attacks and dishing out massive physical damage via combart arts or unique arts, others will be able to cast spells that tear apart entire armies, hex and cripple enemy combatants in every way possible or destroy enemy morale (morale is one big factor in battles too). Some will be able to support unions and heal allies, and others will use traps, explosives, shards to cripple and destroy the enemy.Way too many skills to list here again!On top of the gameplay, The Last Remnant has a really sweet story and amazing graphics.The Xbox version was great, but the PC version improves everything and adds many more features, far too many to list here.The demo is free to download on steam, so you should definitely give it a shot. The game is really cheap to buy too, is £2.99 in pretty much every steam sale. Even when it is not on sale, it is only £7.99.I can't recommend this game enough, it really is epic.

Again, minor annoyance, but it is pervasive, and for this reason I had to complete the game on my Xbox instead (notice the 1.5 game hours on record).I feel this game's story was a solid pitch, but then poor dialogue and (english) acting, as well as an experimental battle system gone awry have left it collecting dust. It's unfortunate, considering an epic story is only 1/3 of the formula that makes this genre great--the other 2/3 being story delivery and battle system, where this game falls horribly short.Can't a guy dream for the return of the original turn-based encounter system? Tried and true, it's what put this genre on its feet. What on earth was so wrong with it? Don't fix something that isn't broken.11.9GB of squandered potential.

content:
er 26, 2013
												One of those games that no one has heard of. Made by Square Enix, The Last Remnant is a unique J-RPG and is probably the most underrated and unappreciated game I have ever played.There are many forums, faq sites, and even an entire wiki dedicated to the game, so I'm not the only one who loved it.Amazing gameplay with hundreds of characters to choose from to form your army.The battle system is also very unique; has a squad based battle system with squads (unions) formed using characters you have recruited / allied with.It might seem unneccesarily convoluted at first, but you will see things fall into place as your party and unions expand. You can spend ages just tweaking formations, party combinations and arts.Characters have a massive range of skills too, some will be amazing warriors - evading attacks and dishing out massive physical damage via combart arts or unique arts, others will be able to cast spells that tear apart entire armies, hex and cripple enemy combatants in every way possible or destroy enemy morale (morale is one big factor in battles too). Some will be able to support unions and heal allies, and others will use traps, explosives, shards to cripple and destroy the enemy.Way too many skills to list here again!On top of the gameplay, The Last Remnant has a really sweet story and amazing graphics.The Xbox version was great, but the PC version improves everything and adds many more features, far too many to list here.The demo is free to download on steam, so you should definitely give it a shot. The game is really cheap to buy too, is £2.99 in pretty much every steam sale. Even when it is not on sale, it is only £7.99.I can't recommend this game enough, it really is epic.

content:
er 28, 2014
												I really wanted to like this game i enjoy RPG's and i just finished playing valkyria chronicals and thought this looked like it could be fun. I was mistaken. This game sadly falls into number crunching your party members and hoping for random abilities or battle options to appear before the enemy gets thier opposing random actions or crits. I could be stuck on a battle for an hour and try all kinds of party adjustments, targeting and actions and in the end the battle would only turn out diffrently if i got a critical skill off before the enemy or was lucky enough to press a quick time button in a defense that killed an enemy party instead of just boinking them for 2 damage. This game acts like theres some strategy but in the end, battles often just fall down to who crits a few times first or randoms some massive skill in their attack action. Whats to bad is the enemy doesn't need these things nearly as much as you do and the resulting "difficulty" that is associated with this game is nothing more then redoing a battle enough times until you get the magic combination of chances that result in a win.Also the main charactor is a 5 year old in a teen body. Brash dumb and whiney dont make for a good main charactor. I can understand if hes supposed to be going through a charactor arc, but this kid is an ANNOYING and thoughtless husk. If your going to do childish to start, give me a Tidus style charactor. Young and naive but with somthing admirable so i dont begin the story by hating him.Do yourself a favor and avoid this game unless you enjoy rolling dice once every 5 minutes and hoping for double 6's.

												Game has high system requirements - However it's completely scalable to almost any PC. If you run the game at lower resolutions you will get the letterboxing effect with black bars at the top and bottom of the screen. Voice acting and cut scenes are pretty good and the battle action is pretty interesting. You should use an XBOX 360 controller for the best experience as some battle actions where you can attack an enemy more then once require pushing different buttons, timing it just right so you can attack. The trigger buttons on the XBOX 360 controller is a  little glitchy when your in an open world where enemies - just when you thought you initiated the attack for first chance to strike , you often find yourself at the mercy of an enemy surprise and it may greatly affect the outcome of the battle. For those of you who are used to older Final Fantasy games, this is not just your standard RPG game - you can highly customize your characters and openly choose where or what you want to do next and there are lots of combination choices as far as the weapons and items go. It's not simplistic and suggested that when the game tells you of a tutorial you follow it , or write it down, otherwise it's going to affect the enjoyment of the game.

ry 7, 2015
												Bad!While people with a taste for story-driven JRPGs may have more endurance than I, I only made it 8 hours into the game before I gave up hope for its salvation. Incohesive design occupies every facet of the game, and while screenshots are happy to show you flashy things like CHAIN x87! and Rush changed class to EXPERT LANCER, very few of these elements either mean anything or are explained to any length of detail. I was left feeling punished for leveling up, unrewarded for exploring, and like a spectator for combat rather than an actual participant.A few key points of obviously bad things:-Boss fights, or "Boy, I hope it doesn't use its AoE attack and oneshot my whole team!"-Boss fights, or "What do you mean that creature that looks almost exactly the same as other creatures I've fought is a boss?"-Boss fights, or "Aww it's a cute little squid this should be eas OH DEAR GOD IT KILLED EVERYTHING"-Turbo mode, or "Yeah, we get that there's a massive disparity in difficulty between normal fights and bossfights, so we put this in to let you literally fastforward gameplay. That's not a red flag, is it?"-AI-controlled unions, or "After playtesting, we concluded that letting the player have any control was harmful to our collection of gameover screens."-PC dying = gameover, or "Sure combat is mostly a spectator's sport, but we feel letting the computer fight itself crosses the line, so we just made the player gameover instead."3/10. It's pretty bad, but I'll leave it with 3 points for people who don't mind this sort of thing.

content:
, 2016
Product received for free
The Developer Square Enix 	The Last Remnant is a classic Japanese role-playing game published and developed by Square Enix, the creators of the Tomb Raider, Hitman, Just Cause, some of the Deus EX games such as the original on PC and Human Revolution as well as the creator of Life is Strange and are most recognized through their work with the Final Fantasy series that became a hallmark for later Japanese Role-playing games that have followed in their footsteps. Summary/Overview  	The Last Remnant is a certified triple A title made by Square Enix first released in 2008 as an Xbox 360 console exclusive never ported to the PlayStation 3. You play as a young man named Rush Sykes, the main protagonist of the game. Your sister, Irina Sykes has been kidnapped by an anti-remnant group that believes that everyone who uses these remnants are corrupt leaving the gods of the power invested in the remnants displeased. The man in charge of this anti-remnant activist group is no other than a distinguished man, Wagrum clothed in a white robe with some gold tethers upon first meeting him. It is similar to some type of robe a bishop of a church would wear but instead of it being red, it is all white with gold tethers. He is a corrupt leader that wants to trick your sister, Irina Sykes into following him, working for him. He has connections with Rush and Irina’s parents who do research over at the academy on remnants. He is actually a member himself of the academy but wants to harness the power of all remnants in order to ensue chaos and cause the unbounded remnants, ones that are not bound to become unstable causing chaos and destruction in the environment around you. 	Remnants are treasures found throughout maps in the game that are considered to hold great power. Usually each remnant is bound by a particular god of some sort and bound to a person. Once a person is bound to a remnant, you can't obtain it for yourself to harness that same power. You will want to be thorough throughout every corridor and open every door along each city-state, territory in order to sometimes find a remnant key. A remnant key is a key in the form of a remnant that can be used to unbind a designated person to that remnant and proceed forward to new places in the game. Monsters (Normal & Rare) 	The last part of history you need to know that sets up the story are the monsters. You will fight monsters constantly in battle in order to level up certain attributes such as intelligence, strength, health and experience points. Monsters range from normal encounters to limited rare monsters. These rare monsters are quite similar to the Pokémon series, yet, they don't run away when you first encounter them. Instead, they despawn after a certain period of time. You want to make sure that if you see one, that you get to it as soon as possible or else it will disappear.     During the time of this initial review I have only played around seven hours. I encountered one rare monster in Dillmoor named Longbeak during that time. I researched and unlike the other rare monsters that reappear, Longbeak does not. Instead, Urraco will appear replacing Longbeak. Others also sometimes only spawn once when you find a new area, while others, are fulfilled through other objectives as you progress in the game.     Apparently each rare monster has a normal location they spawn at.  However, they are extremely overpowered so I recommend trying to revisit places once your battle rank and hit points in damage in individual units and as a union increases. For example, I was only battle rank five or six I think near the time I encountered Longbeak while he ranges fifteen through seventeen base battle rank without a bonus. However, it can appear within a maximum battle rank of sixty-six which for you means that you will have to grind experience points as much as you do more likely in a Monster Hunter game developed by Capcom. The worst thing about Longbeak that makes it a pain to fight is it multi-deadlocks automatically up to three unions. This means that it has you pinned from multiple sides usually.     You can't heal your teammates during this time because if you cancel an initial deadlock once deadlock has already been activated by the opposing union, it will perform a raidlock in which it can attack long range preventing you from further being able to flank the rare monster, Longbeak in our example I am using. A flank is where your whole union at once can attack the object from the left, right side while pinning it down. Longbeak's statistics on the personal computer version range deals twenty-seven thousand five-hundred seventy-one hit points through one hundred seventy-nine thousand three-hundred twenty-two. Gameplay (Features, controls, graphics and mechanics) Features     Turn based combat   Battle ranking system     This is the experience point system that the game has. Instead of Final Fantasy and most Japanese role-playing games that show you what experience level your character and whole party is at one time, in the Last Remnant, we instead have battle ranks. The battle ranking system make it more perilous because you can't see how many experience points you have until the next rank or know when your party members will gain more health, experience points and attributes.Non-Western Traditional Storyline     The main feature that separates western role-playing games from Japanese role-playing games, their main counterpart, is that western role-playing games rely on an expansive open-world that you can explore freely as you choose and they normally have interactive panned cutscenes that contribute less to social order and politics than its counterpart, Japanese role-playing games do. The Last Remnant is no exception to this rule and follows a similar pattern to The Legend of Heroes: Trails of Cold Steel. You have an academy that serves as the commonplace of intelligent design, intellect, history, academia and knowledge of all the towns, city-states, provinces and areas you visit in the game as a whole unit. The storylines also follow a much different and unique pattern remaining linear, is contiguous from area to area and nonanomalous whereas western role-playing games normally have a non-linear storyline that changes from place to place. The Controls/ Camera     They are on point, awesome when the controller vibrates and one hundred percent responsive. The camera controls take a while to get used to based on your preference of adjustment but overtime measure off well. A controller is highly recommended for this game.The Good & BadPositives•	Superb storyline with great voice acting and characters•	Good variation between monsters, city-states and towns•	Nice combat system•	Challenging boss battles•	Good PlayStation 2 style graphics similar to the Legend of Heroes series & Kingdom Hearts 2•	No achievementsNegatives•	Repetitive gameplay•	Arduous experience point and leveling system•	Battles sometimes left to chance, luck•	Long main story estimated sixty-three hours, longer than Dragon Age: Inquisition, Final Fantasy series and some games in the Legend of Heroes series.Overall 7/10Key1-3= poor3-5= ok6-7= good8-10= amazingDisclaimer     I received this game for review purposes from Steamified. All these reviews are unsponsored, unsolicited meaning that I am not entitled to favor all reviews with either a positive or negative score for any games I am sent for review. This review is part of the Steamified Community Review program. For similar reviews and fantastic giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/

content:
14, 2016
												Don't be like me and play all the way through this. Don't download it in the first place.The story is generally stupid and mostly told through a series of long and boring cutscenes. The dialogue for these is poor, and the "editing" is strange with frequent awkward pauses between various characters' speech.Combat is a total mess. The leveling system is skill usage based, but the actual choice of skills to use on each turn is random. Characters change class based on what skills they use most, which is again, largely random, The whole game has incredibely broken level autoscaling, so that characters acquired later have no chance of catching up in power to those obtained earlier. Level design and pacing are odd as well. Later dungeons are larger and more difficult to navigate for no apparent reason. There is one point toward the end of the game which is cutscene, cutscene, long walk through an empty dungeon type area, followed by another cutscene. The score is great, which might be the only redeeming feature of this game, but not enough to make up for the mess which is basically every other aspect of this game.To repeat, don't play this.

content:
er 8, 2016
												I got Last Remnant on sale so I got it for super cheap. I was very excited about finally getting my hands on it but unfortunately that exitement turned into frustration and finally into rage quitting the game just within 6 hours of playtime. While the game does have many good points like a fantastic soundtrack, beautiful visuals comboed with an interesting story and combat system it has some seriously frustrating elements as well. Firstly the game does'nt do a very good job of explaining most of it's mechanics, google is almost a necessity if you really want to understand the game mechanics. The second major issue is the randomness of combat. Sometimes the combat can feel really random especially early on in the game where it feels like you're at the mercy of the enemy AI units and your own ally AI units. I spent 4 hours trying to fight this one early boss called the fiery idol whic you will face an hour or 2 into the game depending on how you play it. The Fiery idol was pretty frustrating even after completing all the side quests I could find and upgrading my weapons to a good degree. If the boss decided to use its powerful AOE firebomb that chops 70% to 60% of your health on turn 2 the you're certainly dead and havve to restart fight. This is the boss that made me give up on the game. No matter what choice I made in fighting this boss it eventually boiled down to RNG deciding my fate. Will the boss use its ultimate on turn 2? will my AI companions who I can't order randomly heal me? It felt really infuriating. I finally did manage to defeat the boss and I reloaded the game to see iof I can replicate by making the same decisions but I had no success. If you are somebody who isnt frazed by a "healthy" dose  RNG you might actually be able to enjoy this game. But, for me its not probably going to happen an Im deleting it from my PC.

A Guide for The Last Remnant
By: Zloth

			There are a lot of things in Last Remnant that I really think should have been explained to the player. In this guide, I try to cover those things without spoiling the story.		


SPOILER SPOILER SPOILERSPOILER SPOILER SPOILERSPOILER SPOILER SPOILERSPOILER SPOILER SPOILERSPOILER SPOILER SPOILERSPOILER SPOILER SPOILERSPOILER SPOILER SPOILER It is an annoying linear walking simulator game. content:
7, 2016
												I loathe JRPGs with a passion (I'm Asian and speaks Japanese so stop with your racism accusations). This game presented itself (at first) as the antithesis of JRPGs: no grinding, large scale, 18-member combat, and customizable party. But once you get to meat of the game (>10hr in) it really begins to fall apart.Pros:- Avoids most boring mechanics of JRPGs e.g. grinding and random combat- Servicable story and protagonist. Rush is less emo and annoying than most JRPG male protagonists. You may even like him quite a bit.- Combat successfully conveys the epicness of an 18-member army w/o feeling (too) repetitive and clunky.Cons:- Combat tends to last very long and after a while it really starts to get boring; there're no ways of escaping or skipping combat animations either.- The game simply refuses to explain its own mechanics to you. You can't customize your characters directly, instead they will randomly ask you seemingly inconsequential questions. If you gave a wrong answer it will permenantly lock them out of abilities and skills, rendering them useless.If you're a completionist don't play this game. The game deliberately and actively trolls you by locking you out of character skills and content w/o telling you so. By the time you finish your first playthrough you will have more regrets on your choices rather than feeling accomplishment.

												This game is VERY hard. It's the most RNG combat system I have EVER seen. Yes, you learn how to get advantage over the enemies, by using Right Trigger(because if you don't you're dead). But even so, you get some options in to who group of enemies to attack(seems random what you get). As you can reload your save 10 times and get different combat with the exact same group of mobs. The attacks you make on the enemies can be interfered, and you still get your asses handed to you in 10 jars.And if you get hurt, it's not automatic that you get a healing option, as I said, it's so RNG you wish you weren't born. The story seems pretty good though.They don't seem to have gotten the hang of difficulty in this game, first two missions to get have some pretty hard boss fights, and like since it's so random, you'll reload 10-20 times until you get the correct options in combat, and you don't get flanked over and over by two group of mobs.All in all, this game seems doable(thanks save/load!) but it's definately a timesinker for loading combats over and over. So if you enjoy getting frustrated over the RNG in this, be my guest and try the game!

												This game... It's OK, it's different, but I'm certainly not sure whether I can recommend it as such. Pity there's a "Not Sure" button" to choose from in regards to this. I'm choosing "no" mainly because at best, I can only recommend to try it out for an hour or so before deciding.What it basically tries to achieve is to combine the personal turn-based fighting of the  Final Fantasy games with turnbased unit fighting. To achieve this without making the game bogged down in commands, each unit gets a few overall choices, instead of each person in the unit getting their own command. Magic is a shared resource in the unit that replenish a few points every turn.How well does it achieve this? Well, the main problem is, things tend to turn out rather random. Battles soon turn intensely chaotic, and trying to keep track of everything that is relevant can be quite a task at certain points. Often the same enemy that made short work of your party will easily fall the next time because the game chose some different commands for you to try out. And this makes it hard to feel that you are accomplishing something in terms of smarter fighting.The randomness continues when it comes to leveling up. Oh, to be sure, you can semi-control the leveling of skills, but sometimes it takes ten battles for something to happen with a particular character, and then the next three battles in a row, the same character will gain several stat and skill incrases. There's really no way to know exactly what and how much is needed to get that character to whatever you want it to be.Apart from that, what is there to this game? Well, a fairly typical Square-Enix storyline (which is sort of in its own place, inbetween the JRPG and the CRPG style of story and characters), and... not much else. Sadly, in this modern day and age, these games tend to be rather void of anything to do but plot and combat, and I think that's a shame.

content:
28, 2015
												What a doozy. This game deserves the ultimate award for"in dire need of one more update".So, let's boil it down to the real issue here, the BR system. There are others, but this is the main one, since it forces you to not play the game and grub around till you have the party of characters you want since if you start leveling up BR before you have them, they will never get caught up.In short BR makes everyone stronger, but if you're smart about it, your guys will always be the bestest so no issue there. So once you've got that part set, and decide to try and change it around to accommodate new hires, you quickly realize the mistake and put back in the old guys, who have now lost a bit of their edge. There in lies, the problem. Getting further away from the start of the game makes the whole thing a tight-rope walk of using what you're handed in the first part of the game, which has some great hires btw, and excludes about 1/4 of the other talented available buddies to bring along.So as an rpg perfectionist, it's like the long the game goes, the more dire the feeling of "maybe I'm doing this wrong" builds, till you have to restart thinking it'll be different this time, but alas, the game randomly choosing your skills means you'll never make that mystic group, or mix-tactics group your thinking up.In short, this review is for the hardcore rpg guy. The Last Remnant offers some surface fun and excitement over the strategies you think you'll be able to construct, then just punishes you mid-late game for not specializing enough, which makes for a real drab experience of the same old "do as much damage as possible" thing, which then drags on and on.I keep replaying thinking it'll be different, but the game sorely needs an overall with more union options to accommodate mixed tactics, or being able to multi-deadlock with one union for defensive strategies. Or just, being able to move a unit out of combat to do just long range attacks.

content:
7, 2016
												I loathe JRPGs with a passion (I'm Asian and speaks Japanese so stop with your racism accusations). This game presented itself (at first) as the antithesis of JRPGs: no grinding, large scale, 18-member combat, and customizable party. But once you get to meat of the game (>10hr in) it really begins to fall apart.Pros:- Avoids most boring mechanics of JRPGs e.g. grinding and random combat- Servicable story and protagonist. Rush is less emo and annoying than most JRPG male protagonists. You may even like him quite a bit.- Combat successfully conveys the epicness of an 18-member army w/o feeling (too) repetitive and clunky.Cons:- Combat tends to last very long and after a while it really starts to get boring; there're no ways of escaping or skipping combat animations either.- The game simply refuses to explain its own mechanics to you. You can't customize your characters directly, instead they will randomly ask you seemingly inconsequential questions. If you gave a wrong answer it will permenantly lock them out of abilities and skills, rendering them useless.If you're a completionist don't play this game. The game deliberately and actively trolls you by locking you out of character skills and content w/o telling you so. By the time you finish your first playthrough you will have more regrets on your choices rather than feeling accomplishment.

Things I Wish I Had Known.... 
A Guide for The Last Remnant
By: Zloth

			There are a lot of things in Last Remnant that I really think should have been explained to the player. In this guide, I try to cover those things without spoiling the story.		


SPOILER SPOILER SPOILERSPOILER SPOILER SPOILERSPOILER SPOILER SPOILERSPOILER SPOILER SPOILERSPOILER SPOILER SPOILERSPOILER SPOILER SPOILERSPOILER SPOILER SPOILER It is an annoying linear walking simulator game. At least you don't have to explore much... EXCEPT FORi¡i¡i¡i¡iBIG ♥♥♥ DESERT? BIG ♥♥♥ DESERT!!!!!You can't individually order units to do squat. It's semi random squad based.So you hafta organize your squads with their individual units, that way you know which squads can do what attacks n magics EVEN THEN. YOU STILL CANT DO SHEET. Example.  Most fights when you want to heal? YOU DONT GET THAT OPTION SUCKER!  I have several people with healing abilities in all of my squads, and almost every single dam fight they can't heal when i would like them too.  99% of the time i only get attack\defense commands.in the very beginning, with it's semi awful tutorial throwing you into a battle right away with not much context clues.  it shows you a full army of people to control. I googled it, you can never get that same size 25 people. 5 squads of 5 :*(  only 3\5 or 4\5 of it    so as of this review. i am perhaps 1\4, 1\3 of the game.  and have reached full army capacity so google tells me.  which is 20\25 :*(  so 5 squads of 4. or 4 squads of 5most battles, you will earn item rewards for crafting. Sometimes a character in your party will request it.This get's annoying as hell.  Because I have several characters i want to get the items, but they rarely ask for it.  You can't force it on them, they have to request for it after a battle.You can deny them the item... but still its a rare thing to occur. So unless its a character you don't want upgrading you let them have the item.

content:
20, 2015
												Fascinating but deeply flawed, The Last Remnant is an RPG that seems almost intentionally confusing. Every system goes several layers deep and while the depth is interesting, it's a little too complicated for anyone but the most hardcore fans to enjoy.It wasn't until about 20 hours in that I started to grasp the battle system. Even though I was reading outside information about the game it wasn't as helpful as actually playing the game and after beating the game I'm still not sure about some things. Most people on the internet suggest to keep your battle rating low, but I was constantly running into roadblocks of luck-based fights that were frustrating. Most of the quests are fine. I liked that they take you directly to the area you need to be almost all the time, but they also make you leave right as you finish the quest as well. This isn't a problem except there are several quests that end with items in the room you finish the quest in, and then it instantly teleports you home. I'd rather talk to someone to port me home so I could get that stuff. I completed every quest in the game and felt pretty good about the game going up to the last boss. Completing all the quests screwed me, since the final boss was simply too strong for my team and required way too much grinding to get by. Although it's cool that the game changes depending on how you play almost none of it is obvious at any time.In fact, almost none of the game's systems are surfaced. From some quest parameters to learning skills to equipping friends with items, there is no information at all about the game. The extremely limited tutorial only covers union attacks from different directions. In the Xbox 360 version there are loading screens with tips, but these were taken out of the PC version. Most of the time I resorted to the helpful wiki and an external program that hooks into the game to display things like enemy health and what the heck a class like an "Expert Swashbuckler" does.I found the environments to be boring. So many corridors and caves with few paths that usually just lead to items. A few scenes were pretty, but the majority of the game made me feel claustrophobic.Despite all that, there's something to this game's battle system that is fun and feels good to play with after learning its intricacies. Breaking this game was a joy, learning new spells and training familiar ones is good (though complex) and fighting requires tactics that I rarely see in RPGs. I just wish that stuff was surfaced a lot more in the game.There's a reason that this game still has an active community - this game probably has thousands of ways to play it and no two playthroughs will be the same. If you can get past the massive hurdles that are required to play this, The Last Remnant is a perfectly average RPG that offers a ton of depth in its battle system.

content:
20, 2015
												A jrpg with serious grinding and convoluted story problems, but still worth a play.  The main protagonist is horrible and unintelligent and unlikeable, and I'm starting to think that maybe that was intentional?? He's basically jRPG George Bush Jr. as a teenager.The combat system though is pretty awesome and I wish other games used something like it. A final fantasy 9 remake with this combat system would be the ♥♥♥♥. You have characters and they're put into little squadrons that fight together as a single unit, and how you attack and approach enemies and the angle you use (and subsequently, the ones they use) determine not only your damage bonuses/maluses and the abilities/tricks you can use but also how the morale bar progresses (either towards the enemy side or your side). Understadnably, the morale bar is best on your side, as it has a severe effect on everything.  Its very strateigic and a good play can easily turn the tide of battle in even overwhelming situations. However, a severe downside is the sheer amount of grinding and gathering you have to do. Dear goodness. You can certainly play through the game without doing any but you'll eventually hit a brick wall of 'this is way too hard even if I play this perfectly' 3/4ths through the game (I did that).  You have to grind this, collect that, grind that, grind this, grind that, so your characters all level up in their weapon and level their weapon up and level what weapons they can craft up and level what weapons their crafted weapons can craft up and level what's availible from shops to aid in crafting that sword to craft an axe to switch over to another skill set and do it all over again for 30+ odd characters. Nope. Not for me. Maybe for you?
