content:
, 2013
												Let me just say off the bat, the story in this game is garbage.There are some great NPCs that make it bearable, but as it stands, the game's plot and narrative are not that good.Having said that, everything else in this game is incredible.The combat is simply amazing, at first things may appear to be random, but most of the work comes from you building a working party.Your party consists of unions, and your attacks in the battle are determined by who's in that union and what skills they possess.For instance, if you want a union to have the chance to cast mystic arts, you'd use predominantly mystic art users in that union.You can also turn off characters skills, giving you another level of depth to play with.Aesthetically the game is gorgeous, plenty of effects in battle and clean texture work, it's also runs pretty well on lower end PCs.When it comes to audio, this game is damn near perfect.The voice acting is surprisingly well done, save for the main character, but everything else is top notch.The real star of the game though is easily the soundtrack, there is nothing wrong with it, and the quality is probably the best I've seen this generation.In the end, if you can look past the story being so stale, then you have one of the most unique games on the market right now.I thank god Square Enix decided to port this game, it was decent on the consoles, but it really shines on PC.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
8, 2012
												If you liked FFXII and/or Xenoblade, you should like this. Awesome music and battle system.I really like The Last Remnant. The PC version anyways. While the inability to micromanage every unit's exact move is not present, I found manipulating the battle system and secondary progression systems around it to be extremely enjoyable.It's a bit late so I hope this review doesn't become nonsensical.The battle system involves positioning, unit selection, skill progressions, classes, equipment, a large cast of unique characters with truly unique abilities as well as strengths and weaknesses when it comes to their abilities in battle. You can group up characters in 3 to 5 groups based on whatever criteria you choose, selecting leaders of each group to help direct the given selection of battle commands based on their class and it's a requirement if you want to use their unique ability (and forfeit that of their supporting units). The group formation selection can be used to further a unions strength or cover up a weakness of the composition of the group. A 5 man union packs a stronger punch and is harder to take down in most cases, but more unions give you more flexibility in what you can complete in a given round,The PC version offers extended control where you can take each and every unit and enable or disable any specific ability for any of them individually, which offers an extent of control not found in the 360 version. There's a lot of skills in the game, short range magic, long range magic, hexes, item combinations, single or duel wielding or two handed weaponry, even morale type items whose skill type escapes me at the moment. The protagonist can go in whatever direction you desire and all of the rest of the cast will branch out in whichever selection of a given handful you choose for them. There are nearly infinite possibilities to how you form your final 18 man army.The battles system itself, outside of secondary systems, is also very deep. You can gang up your unions on a single enemy to induce incounterable back attacks and overwhelm them at the cost of leaving your own flank open, or pair friendly and enemy unions up two-by-two and simply win out slowly on all fronts. Knowing when to keep distance and build AP or fall back to provide a heal or a cleanse is also imperative, as well as knowing how to abuse insta-dodges provided by casting a limit break (or whatever they are called).There's lots of interesting bosses, especially in the PC version that mirrors the 360 dlc, where battles will test your ability to fight on many fronts or clear a high HP single target out in five or fewer turns. Shows how many ways there are to construct a battalion and execute an encounter.The fact that battles have dynamic ( and awesome) music selections based on the strength/rarity of the enemy and the flow of the battle is just gravy.The story provides enough motivation to keep you playing, which is all I could ask for from a JRPG. None of the characters are terrible, though few are remarkable. The VA performance is good on average, minus a few characters whose actor didn't seem to give a ♥♥♥♥ (Irina.)One of my favorite games of the last few years.9/10

												While this game can seem cheesy (doesn't even matter whether you've got the audio in English or Japanese), the combat and completionism are more than addicting enough to make up for it.  Once I start playing I just keep going for more combat over and over because it is so engrossing to me.  The music is enjoyable and fitting as well, especially how it changes up through a single combat depending on how you're doing...Concerning the story....negative: the story is mainly told through hints at it; positive: if you pay attention you can figure out the entire story if you do all the side quests, and it leaves you slightly wistful.Summary: Do get it for the combat; do get it for the music.  Do NOT get it for the voice acting, and unless you appreciate cheese, do not get it for the story (although I actually like it).Also, in one respect this game is rather like Ragnarok Online - not in the slightest having to do with gameplay.  There is so much information that if you only have time to play and not to figure out all the mechanics and under-mechanics of how classes work and where items come from, you need the wiki.  Whoever all made the wiki is absolutely insane and worthy of adoration.

content:
ry 21, 2014
												This JRPG is something I consider and underrated gem. Story 6/10The story is generic but not too generic to the point where it's unplayable. It has its moments but is dragged down by its predictability. There is a decent plot twist at the end but it doesn't help rate it any higher. Stories of unique mercenaries you hire are told through their conversations and related missions. Most of them do have an interesting background (Nora, Violet, etc.). But they could have expanded more on their stories which was dissapointing to say the least.Gameplay 8.5/10The heart of the game is in the gameplay. You can have up to 18 units in your team, split into a maximum of 5 groups called unions. Each character can learn various skills (with Rush being the only one that can learn every move except for Weapon Specific Arts) and their usage of skills gives them roles the field. However, you can only manually equip Rush with whatever he is able to hold.The others upgrade and request either weapons or components on their own (what they request is based on your Battle Rank and what path you chose for them) The combat system itself is turn based strategy. You have to be smart about what abilities you keep on and what commands you choose. You do not specifically choose what they will do in that turn but you can influence their decisions based on their path and what skills you keep on or off. The combat is very deep and doing a full in-depth review of it would take too long. Try the demo to see if it is your taste. HOWEVER, I must say that looking at various guides (especially the wiki for the game) is very useful in order to understand the stat gain system and its relationship to the Battle Rank system. You may be familiar with the stat gain system if you have played any of the SaGa RPGs (which makes sense because the developer also worked on the SaGa games as well)Graphics 7/10It is the Unrea Engine so the moves look pretty when they're the flashy moves. Sadly, it is also Square Enix's first attempt using the Unreal Engine so there are many texture pop-in issues (but they recover in a few seconds). The environments without Remnants are relatively bland compared to the areas where Remnants are visible. Music 9/10The music is great for each scenario. The fights in open areas is very energetic, the fights in closed areas have a feeling of suspense. The music also changes during fights to match the current morale of the team. If it is low, then the music becomes darker, if the morale is high, it makes you feel like kicking ♥♥♥.Overall, I give it an 8/10

												You would think that a JRPG would have good schematics in terms of a battle system. The Last Remnant would tell you otherwise. Story gives a generic "adventure for x objective", without character development. Grapics are decent for running on an Unreal engine. However, gameplay is lackluster and doesn't deserve good praise. It has you controlling multiple "teams" while not giving you individual character control in case of needed emergencies. If one character on a team does an action based on your decision, they ALL have to act in that manner. The big problem is that whenever you think the battle is over, more enemies come in to extend the pointless auto-battle. Get a Final Fantasy title, or any other JRPG that can give you better character development.

												The graphics are really sparse and the voice acting is hit-or-miss. The music and the storyline are decent. The gameplay is alright, you have your dudes in "unions" and give them orders, but often can't micromanage what every guy does. Item use, plot progression, how to use unions, morale -- all this stuff is opaque and the game doesn't explain well.Also the battles start getting really hard, so you have to grind a bunch, which isn't something that I really like doing. This game has an obnoxious fan base of people who are really dedicated to a mediocre game.

content:
, 2014
												Before i start, i almost always finish games i start, even if they are bad. This game however got to a point that it was unwinable. The console version was apparently too easy so they ramped up the difficulty scaling on the pc version, which they overdid. Im still interested in the story, i just got to the point where i couldnt kill anything, and to fix it i would have to scrap my save and start again. Ill elaborate though... there are no levels in this game, your main character just gets ranks which are like level ups where you get random points based on what you killed. HOWEVER the game tricks you into thinking you can just fight large groups of enemies to get a larger reward, what it really means is to ONLY fight the tough enemies, otherwise when you rank up you get points based on the weak enemies, which is to say you barely get stat increases but the enemies get tougher. Rank up enough this way and the game becomes unwinnable. I only found out what i was doing wrong about half way into the game and the only way to correct it is to start from the beginnning again. I couldnt do any of the sidequests to beat elite enemies because they often just one shotted me. That said the correct way of playing this game is to pick up the strongest allies, avoid every enemy you can and only fight bosses or elite enemies as part of sidequests to keep your rank down as low as it can go. This game greatly discourages revisiting areas and grinding (such as farming the parts to craft a good weapon). I may someday return to this game in an attempt to beat it, but having to restart because i farmed too much seems like a bad gameplay design.

content:
, 2016
												October 11, 2016: Completely Revised Review. The first review failed to acknowledge the positives of The Last Remnant and rambled on the negatives far too much.(Note: I have already beat the game on normal and hard mode without cheats/changes to the game engine. Further playthroughs were altered for convienence and fun.) Upon entering the world of The Last Remnant, I came across an incredibly intriguing game. There was an entire fantasy world and multiple systems to uncover and understand. The beautiful world and atmosphere of TLR had captivated me; however, the game was marred by a complete lack of information for mechanics, a multitude of unpolished gameplay systems, and a shallow combat system that ruined the experience and credibility of the game. Even despite the flaws, The Last Remnant had succesfully conveyed a myriad of small details that made the game feel exhilarating. The crisp and powerful sound design bolsters the strike of a weapon and the destruction from a casted ability; my ears became addicted to it all while my eyes were graced by the gigantic damage numbers dished out by my units. Even more so, the OST of this game is absolutely superb. From the tranquil melody of Echoes of the Past to the heart-pumping Press to Victory, the composers from Square Enix demonstrate their mastery over music. As someone who is fond of fantasy armor and design, TLR has also solidly designed a memorable cast of characters. Regardless of any cliches or annoyance that comes from them, there's no doubt that they're distinct and recognizable from their cheesy one-liners to their small yet endearing personalities and backstories. Despite all these wonderful aspects about the game, I am pained to say that the gameplay has nullified the many positives I have for TLR. The combat is riddled with RNG, from choosing my commands, to the outcome of a skirmish, and even to my ultimate abilities, most of one's ability to strategize becomes reduced to constant dice rolls and enemy attacks that do absurdly little damage or completely wipe out a union. There is also no median of difficulty to be had in TLR either. It's either a dull cake-walk or a frustratingly difficult and cheap end-game playthrough.Even worse, many systems in the game feel overlooked and unrefined, such as commerce points, combat, exploration, customization, guild quests, and crafting. Ultimately, It is disappointing to say that this game is just a wasted potential. There's no doubt that it is an amazing foundation and base for a potentially grand RPG like no other, but it just falls short tremendously.To conclude, The Last Remnant is my guilty pleasure since it has accomplished visual and audio designs to near perfection, (especially for 2009!) but in the end, I'm just playing a beautiful board game with a tremendous waste of potential.

content:
ber 5, 2016
												The Last Remnant introduce you to many unique systems when it comes to combat, party management , crafting & loot. Non of them and I mean NON works right. At the beginning everything seems okay and understandable but at the moment you get in with the rhythm of the game, it leaves you alone without even explaining any necessary part of any RPG game like crafting for example. And you say to yourself: OK I'll get hold of it the more I play. But you wont. The game will be more complex and you'll feel lost. Sure you'll keep pushing forward finishing a quest after quest but you feel that there is something that you don't quiet get. When I found myself in this position I decided to read some guides in order to understand what I'm doing wrong. And then it was easy to realize that even the people who made those guides (that are mostly helpful) does not understand many sections of the game.Take me for an example. I'm 50 hours into the game. I haven't bought anything from any merchant. I haven't crafted a single item even though that I have tons of components. I don't know what does a characters class means. I don't know half of the stats that my characters have like love, luck or courage because there is no way to monitor them. The game is vague about everything it has and it is not willing to show you anything so you have to treat it like Dwarf Fortress and go and read pages after pages of info that the game should have taught you at early hours of gameplay (if it was a good game).Let me tell you about level design. If you are exploring one of it's small and peaceful towns or a natural place then it's okay. But the most parts you will be running through castles, caves & temples that are designed like a really boring and empty mazes. I was once into a castle to do a side quest. I miraculously managed to find my way to my target without a map with everything explored except for a small hallway near the end of the level (you always find the map in a chest somewhere). So after I reached my destination and finished the side quest the game automatically takes me out of the place back to where I started it. Then I got curious maybe I'll find something useful at the hallway that I did not explore. So I decided to get back to the castle battle the stupid respawned enemies and waste half an hour just so that I find a map of the place that I have no business in no more! This is how stupid the level design is in this game.One of many pointless ant totally worthless side quests was a guy telling me that he lost something and this "Something" has been broken into six parts and I have to search for those parts and bring it back to him! even a 6 years old would have the imagination to make a better side quests than these.I could spend all night writing about every single bad thing about this game from it's uninteresting pokemon-like companion (which is called mister diggs - lack of imagination again) to it's bad looking enemies with their repetitive moves to it's boring and disgusting grinding and leveling up system.I could tell you about everything that I encountered and diminished my enjoyment of the game. But I guess that is enough. You can still give it a try because it's cheap but I don't recommend doing it.

content:
ber 25, 2016
												So I originally played the console version of this game, and got nailed by the game-breaking coding. Not a bug, just a somewhat infamously poor design choice that could easily render the game unbeatable halfway through. Hearing that that was fixed, I decided to try the PC version and get the game's full experience. And I just can't; the aforementioned flaw overshadowed the more important fact that this game is BORING. I like the story, but the presentation and setting are rather lackluster, alot of obvious questions are never asked, the pacing is weird, and the main character rivals Tidus for being just an annoying, foolish lead. Really, that highlights the most noteworthy aspect of this game; it's JRPG as you can get, in the worst way. Even as a lifelong fan of the genre, my favorite one, there are things that are just irritating in it, and this game seems to take them all and magnify them. Everything about the game feels so RANDOM. The damage you deal, and receive, jumps around tremendously, I mean by literal orders of magnitude. One guy, with the same attack stat, can do 30 damage, and the next one will do several THOUSAND, no lie, no hyperbole, that is what happens. You have no direct control over characters, instead issuing vague commands to character clusters and hoping for the best (good luck getting them to heal, it seems to be the hardest thing to do). And there is some requirement for you to command the battlefield itself, choosing which enemy units to hit, but with no rhyme or reason to the order of who gets to attack, you can often find yourself being intercepted when trying to attack a group of enemies literally three feet in front of you by another group of enemies 40 feet off. What? And while damage to the character groups is pooled, mostly, it is still possible for you to lose individual members of the group for no real reason, drastically hurting your potential. You have a morale meter in battle, which increases your damage and decreases the damage you take, but it always favors whoever is winning the fight, meaning the better side gets better and the worse side gets worse; in the end, what it means is that you absolutely dominate already easy opponents while getting creamed by powerful ones you might otherwise might have had a shot at. Increasing your party's power simply involves finding them random items from monster drops that they just keep and somehow use on their equipment, or occasionally carrying around equipment and hoping they eventually ask you if they can use it. There are no straight levels in this game, instead playing like Chrono Cross where every fight will probably give at least one character some minor boost to a stat, like 2 HP or something. However, leveling isn't much use, since enemies level with you, more or less. You also have this little guy who can mine for resources for you, but only so many times, and it's very random.It's very difficult to fully describe this game's issue without giving detailed explanations of every mechnanic, but let me sum it up; if you are not a fan of JRPGs, run away from this one, you will hate it. If you are a fan, ask yourself if these are the kinds of mechanics you like, where you basically require a guide to play effectively, everything is very random, and the game involves lots of repetivive grinding through the same tiny areas against the same 3 kinds of enemies for hours just to get certain drops or to do the 5th quest in the same location. I was hoping to enjoy this game all the way through this time, but I'm even less tolerant of it's problems today than I was 6 years ago. It's just too annoying and repetitive to play, causing controller-busting frustration over the game's predominately AI controlled combat acting really stupid. In a way, the best comparison I can think of is Enchanted Arms; both have servicable if predictable plots with typical Japanese tropes, both have unique combat systems to try and hang their hat on (and failing), and both are so plagued by mechanics and randomness that don't make any realistic sense and lack any reason to exist that it makes the games simply un-fun. If it had a traditional leveling system without monsters leveling with you, higher movement speed, higher drop rates, more info giving to you, less randomness and more control in combat, I could enjoy the game, even with it's flaws. But it's just too slow and plodding and annoying to enjoy the decent parts of it, and novelty of the combat system isn't enough to carry an otherwise mediocre-to-poor title. You better be a total JRPG fanatic to play this.

content:
ber 29, 2014
												Do you like RPGs? If yes proceed to the next question.Do you like grinding? If no you can stop here, you might need some patience and time to play this game.If you are expecting a A-RPG, do not be fooled this game is not that.Last remnant is a fantastic JRPG with a novel combat system that feels like a breeze of fresh air in this game industry where every game last 5 hours and is full of cinematics (there are plenty of cinematics in TLR do not fear). The combat system feels random at times until you learn how the system works, problem is this is going to take at least 50h and you are not going to have a grasp of all the things you can actually do. The story is alright, considering the main character is less charismatic than a potato and he is annoying as hell, but a mysterious and charismatic antagonist pays off.Pros:- Cheap.- Loads of content and beautiful areas.- Really nice visuals.- AoE synergies and group building.- Difficulty through the roof, that makes you build up some self confidence when you get to kill THAT ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ MONS-- er.- ♥♥♥♥ loads of upgrades to weapons and skills.- Customization of your units and characters make the game an experience every time you play it.Cons:- Main character annoying as hell.- Side quests blocking the full content of the game, especially in some cases when you needed to do a quest from Disc 1 in order to go into a new zone (e.g. The ancient runes.)- Guild rewards need you to kill some random monster that has a 0.01% spawn ratio.- Almost mandatory to follow a guide during your first playthrough.Veredict: 7 out of 10.

content:
y 16, 2016
												i really wanted to like this game but i can't. i reached the last boss but i gave up, just saw a video about the ending and disinstalled it. SPOILERS-characters have 0 personality-the story is written by a special kid.. it revolves around the remnants but no info about what they are and what they do. they decided to give to everycity a remnant but apart being something cool to see they do nothing at all-incredibly stupid game mechanic (AVOID TO ACTUALLY PLAY to be able to finish it.... really??)-you can't control what your characters do in battle.. YOU ARE ALONE, RESURRECT THE OTHER CHARACTERS! NO! WHY ARE YOU ATTACKING?? -the story is so bad that i have to talk a bit about it..... at some point the BAD guy shows up and his name is THE CONQUEROR, just the fact that his name is a noun should be enough but at this point the special kid decides to give it all, for no reason the god emperor (another character that exists in this game only for 20 seconds purpose) knows that THE CONQUEROR is a remnant (it is supposed to be a surprise but the special kid decided to make all the character give hints about it almost as soon as THE CONQUEROR appears) and he orders everyone to obey to what he wants, there are also come very cool evil characters like the imba mage with a cool burned eye (of course with 0 background) that again for no reasons wants to help THE CONQUEROR to kill all the humans. why does THE CONQUEROR want to kill everyone? because people are abusing the remnants (it is unknown in what way they are using them since the only remnant used in the game is the gae bolg.. all the other remnants are purely for city decorations)-the BIG PLOT TWIST!!! the main character (which i forgot to tell you is completely brain damaged) is actually a remnant too! OMG...  too bad the special kid did it again by making HUGE hints about it from the first moment you meet THE CONQUEROR (like him appearing like a star wars jedi ghost to the main character's sisters and telling her that he is... the scene doesn't show what he tells her, probably that her brother is a remnant but most probably nothing important because she doesn't give a flying f*** about this revelation for all the game.. or the other scene when THE CONQUEROR tells the main character "remember who you truly are" or that other time when he tells him "you should have regained the memory by now" or maybe even when he tells him "you should know what i am going to do because the mission to kill the humans wasn't originally mine" you pick one-the subquests, nothing wrong with them, the only problem is again the game mechanic to unlock certain quests.. for example a quest with an unlockable character is only avaible if in the middle of the main quest (at a certain point you have to attack 6 enemy bases) after conquering each enemy base you go to this character and talk to him because REASONS! let me be clear.. you attack first base.. go to talk to character.. go back to attack 2nd base.. go back to talk to character.. get it? how clever is it? CLEARLY NOT A QUEST DOABLE ONLY IF YOU FOLLOW A GAME GUIDE-there are way more things to talk about but i am tired and you should have got the pointSpecial note about how i wanted to punch the main character everytime he sayd DAVE... ♥♥♥♥ing retard meets a lord of a city, that for no reason (are you still surprised that in this game things just happens?) decides to help him, and when he gets announced by his generals as the marchese david nassau, he promptly exclaims some ♥♥♥♥ things like "nice to meet ya DAVE"

CLEARLY NOT A QUEST DOABLE ONLY IF YOU FOLLOW A GAME GUIDE-there are way more things to talk about but i am tired and you should have got the pointSpecial note about how i wanted to punch the main character everytime he sayd DAVE... ♥♥♥♥ing retard meets a lord of a city, that for no reason (are you still surprised that in this game things just happens?) decides to help him, and when he gets announced by his generals as the marchese david nassau, he promptly exclaims some ♥♥♥♥ things like "nice to meet ya DAVE"

content:
er 26, 2013
												 I often equate this game to the JRPG equivalent of a bad B-movie, which can be considered both a good and a bad thing, depending on what you’re expecting going in.Between the thin story and terrible voice acting just getting through the first few cut-scenes will likely be enough to push most players away from the game entirely. That having been said, if you do decide to give the game a shot, the terrible acting does let up a bit after you get about 10 hours into the main quest side of the game, and the story starts to pick up a bit even if it still follows many of the standard JRPG clichés.Gameplay-wise, The Last Remnant is very ‘hands-off’. The party system mechanics are actually rather interesting, allowing you to recruit members to add to your party and split them up into groups for combat, but it falls short due to the fact that you have no control over those recruits equipment or skills. Gaining new skills requires that a previous skill in the same ‘tree’ is used in combat to give a chance for a new skill to be learned or an old one to be upgraded but even that is left up to a modicum of randomness, unfortunately making the entire system an endeavor of patience and repetition.The battle system is likely where you will either learn to love the game despite itself or simply hate it enough to give up entirely. To put it simply, you have almost no control whatsoever. Instead you are given a series of choices based on various factors, such as party/enemy levels, active party skills, party/enemy/ally HP, etc. It is possible to lean the options in a certain direction by disabling non-useful abilities before entering combat so that they are not available as a choice, but even then you may still get turns where your mage-only group is given only physically offensive options.Once you get far enough to have 3 groups battles become a bit easier to handle. If you manage to stick around long enough to get to 4 groups, however, the combat system starts to shine a bit, adding in more potential tactics and a better balance for the battles. It’s really at this point that both the gameplay and the story start to pick up and become more fluid all around.I personally have enjoyed my time playing The Last Remnant, but I went into it fully expecting it to be severely lacking in some areas, and as such will be the first to admit that it is not for everyone. It takes a long time to actually get to the fun parts of the game, but once you’re there it’s… well, fun.It’s not epic or life changing, but if you want to play a JRPG that’s a bit different and have the patience to make this one work, then keep a look-out for when it goes on sale and give it a shot. Otherwise, you will most likely be better off passing this one up.

er 27, 2013
												The Last Remant is a game made by the well known Square Enix group, which is the main reason i purchaced it (despite the low rating). After a little bit of messing around here and there with the large array of video settings, I stepped off into the game and realized quickly that it was just another generic japanese rpg. Some overpowered guy has caputred some innocent girl and you (being the brother) must go rescue her. Despite the generic storyline, the gameplay is not bad if you like cluttered screens. A good 80% of the screen is filled with some sort of box telling you something (during combat). The tactical perspectives of the game (such as being able to flank someone in mid-combat for a boost to moral and etc) makes for great mechanics, however it is drowned out by not feeling the true immersion of a square enix title. I wouldn't recommend buying this game unless you do not mind generic storyline, low immersion, high clutterence titles.

content:
ry 2, 2014
												While the battle system is interesting, and certainly different than the usual affair for an RPG, it misses the mark... as does the rest of this game. The turn based battle system puts you in control of multiple "troops" who operate with vague and often times unpredictable mechanics. You would expect that since you are incharge of a small army, you would also have a good understanding of the terran, troop movements, ect. Wrong. You have no sense of space whatsoever during any point of the battle. This eliminates gameplay as sound strategy and makes each encounter a crapshoot with the player often times hoping for the best.As for the characters and story... there is none. The characters are souless and without clear motivations. Their relationships are never well established or developed. Essentially, everybody is just there and has a loose reason to be on this "quest". The story is choppy, full of glaring plot holes and is as ill defined as its characters. It gives no real sense of threat or urgency when it's time to go out and face the bad guys, nor does it explore why each character would be vested in the story's goals. You just have to do cuz there's nothing else to do... except side quests. Speaking of...The side quests are a bunch of repetative nonsense that feel tacked on to the story and service no real purpose except to be finished by completionists. (This is not to say that other RPG's do it better, but it contributes to the souless nature of this game. There is just no drive, interest or reason to really do much of anything. You do it because it's there. The end.)At least the art and music are good. But if that's all that interests you... Go to the symphony.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
19, 2014
												So I'd gotten wind of this game by multiple peers who all claimed it to be the pinnacle of PC RPG's and sadly I have to find myself agreeing with them. Why I say 'sadly' it's due to the fact that The Last Remnant has left a void in me that not even it could fill; only create.There's really nothing to be said of great deal about the story of TLR. For the most part the entire storyline was rather predictible with some characters showing insight that could've been called character if they'd decided to act more upon it, sadly only a few characters recieve any amount of characterization, but again the entire story is generic to begin with, so it doesn't surprise me in the least.This leads me to the gameplay which I'm quite sad to say was extremely disappointing. While on the surface, any new player might look at the gameplay and see an extemely complex and quizzling battle system, the verteran would easily deny such. The combat consists of 'squads' in which you assign a formation to the squad and create who is in the squad. Sadly everyone but the main character is entirely uncustomizable and is only upgraded through fulfilling their needs when they ask (which again is out of the players hands). Battles that seemed to have a sort of strategy with positioning will not let the player decide where the squad stands or allow the squad to run backwards from the enemy. Almost every action in the battles is entirely randomly generated and while you can check what actions will take place with each attack, you cannot choose every action for your attack. For example, say you want the main character to use 'Blue Bird', you would have to check each option to see if he even has the CHANCE to use it. Oftentimes my characters obtain a completely game-breaking move but decide to use their weaker ones for no reason in particular. While I understand for the main character Rush, you can disable arts for him, to force him into using the OP skills it's simply not possible for the other NPCs. Oh also QTE's are the entire combat. Everytime you tell a squad to attack it has a chance of doing a critical offense/defense in which you have to press a single button/trigger to initiate a stronger attack/counterattack/dodge.I had brought up earlier how you couldn't customize your characters for squads and I'd like to reiterate upon that a little bit more. You cannot give them armor/equipment. You cannot choose their name/appearance. You cannot pick anything about them other than whatever preset the game has given you. While you can choose nameless soldiers, it would be silly to choose those over any of the commanders who are able to learn unique abilities and upgrade their weapons to a higher degree.Lastly many complain of the difficulty that is this game. I can say I breezed through every fight without much struggle. The game is extremely level-dependent and can scale enemies with the characters though not to a noticible degree. I will warn new players of grinding unless they find themselves in a quest to which they cannot complete, I've heard horror stories of those who grinded prior to getting party members and made the game neigh impossible. I will say that grinding/battling is one of the things the game has improved on. Grinding can be sped through, and gaining 10+ levels in 30 minutes is an easy task. Battles are also pretty fun since you can go all out in every battle since the end of every battle results in a completely healed party.P.S. Looking for quests suck and some quests can be skipped. I used a guide (to find questgivers, not spoil the quest) because I will not, WILL NOT, run around in stupid circles looking for a quest in every single city's five sections. Especially since as I've said certain quests are entirely skippable and certain quests will only unlock after doing certain storyline requirements. This means you can check all fourty areas for quests, do a single storymode quest, and then have to check all fourty areas again just in case. I just don't have that kind of commitment in me, and I don't think anyone else should put up with such shenanigans. All quests should have been found in the guilds at every city, there was no reason to do otherwise other than to ♥♥♥♥ people off.Overall I do recommend anyone looking for an RPG on the PC to check TLR out, sadly don't look forward for this game to fill your lust for customizable team building or strategy.

content:
y 1, 2016
												I picked this up as a part of a bundle, expecting nothing much and it was worse off than i thought. The first hours of the game have you in a tutorial where you just follow commands. After I was done with that and finally got control of my own units, i spent about an hour grinding cause the game kinda didn't tell me how to trigger the next flag. The story is bland as oatmeal, with some voiceovers being really cringeworthy.But then to the meat of the game, the combat. Much to the credit of the game, they are trying something new, instead of controlling single characters actions you now control a group of characters (called a Union). The combat system is simple enough with a leveling system even simpler, use stuff and it eventually levels up. Although leveling up doesn't help you much since the game heavily relies on numbers and RNG, what those numbers might be I couldn't tell you, since the game in no way explains it. RNG is also a big factor, when against the same mob (as in reloading a save and actually fighting the same mob) the outcome of the first round was wildly different, ranging from killing a enemy union without getting hit to myself being one-shotted, this against exactly the same mob.The game looks pretty enough (if you can overlook som glitchy graphics) although most of the enviroments seems to be quite boring. The dungeons throws nonsense mechanics at you for no reason at all *door shuts down and you get to fight the same mobs you've been chomping like tic-tacs to get there*. In another dungeon there is a slow-down fog, it does nothing exept slow you down, so instead of wasting 5 seconds running down an empty hallway, you now get to enjoy the same empty hallway for a minute.All in all, the game reminds me alot of FFX, if you take away intresting scenes, combat and story.

												My very minimal time with the game will tell you that I did not like it very much. Firstly, although it is an old game, and animation awkwardness and other graphical issues are to be expected, one would have thought that these would be fixed when the port to PC was made, but I found no sign of that here. When I was introduced to the battle system, my honest thought was, "Ugh, is the entire game going to play like this?" to which more progress into the game told me it was. The battle system is rather confusing at first, and doesn't really get all that better with the explanations further inot the game as I found myself asking where the decisions where in terms of what techniques to use or who to attack with which individual character. Admittedly, since this game was from Square Enix, I was more or less expecting something along the lines of their other fare, which I did not find here. I'm really not the type that likes to control large groups of soldiers or particularly a fan of RTSes, which this game had enough of to make me not want to play any longer.I also wasn't able to get invested in the story right away, and could see that if I was feeling like skipping the cutscenes already, that I wasn't going to enjoy game over all.

content:
y 9, 2014
												Sick of hack n' slash action games posing as the real deal? This is a great way for PC gamers to play a turn-based, strategic RPG, which unfortunately, has been a dying genre for the platform since the 90s. I don't like that it eschews a world map (a terrible trend in Japanese RPGs). However, some of the areas are vast enough to give the feel of a world map, even if you are just picking names of places to go. This isn't as good as Final Fantasy XII, the only FF that wasn't garbage after IX, but it gets the job done. The battle system could have offered more control, but it adds a different kind of strategy with who to target, and when to use what commands you are given the option to use. The texture pop-in of the UT3 engine is bad, and the cutscenes look like crap even after forcing v sync with a third-party app, but the towns and the remnants look cool. There are also many sidequests, and you'll probably need to do a lot of them because the boss battles can be rough.

content:
er 11, 2015
												The Last Remnant is a unique title. It manages to have some of the greatest voices on the face of the planet and still manages to fall short due to its writing. The main character is voiced by Johnny Yong Bosch, so you'd think he'd be able to save the performance, right? Nope, the writing's that dry and cliched...though moreso the former than the latter.What does make this game worth recommending, however, is the gameplay. When I say that the title is unique, I don't mean because of the writing; games have had great voices and bad writing before. What makes this game unique is that it has a style of gameplay unseen since Chaos World back on the NES. Rather than controlling one character at a time and fighting monsters that way, you take several characters into a fight and control them as squads. This isn't a Turn-Based game, either, though it may look it...or not. This game is the type of thing that is hard to decipher from videos alone, but its more of a Tactical Turn-Based RPG, though I wouldn't go as far as to call it a Strategy RPG.This game also lends itself to an OK story, but there's enough here to keep one who is having fun interested for a while. The areas are large and open (and this is not a linear game), the customization is one of the more unique things I've seen out of an RPG, and the character recruitment process is slightly unpolished, among other things in the game, but the idea of having so many optional characters with histories and personalities is a nice touch. If the price is low enough (and this game can go pretty low, price-wise) then I'd definitely recommend checking it out, especially if your looking for a unique experience.

content:
30, 2013
												Last Remnant is a very complex and interesting game with lots of unique mechanics. The problem is that the game doesn't really tell you what those mechanics are or how they work. As a result, a lot of things will just seem random or abritrary unless you look things up in the wiki.If you do spend time on the Wiki, you can find out how arcana magic works, how people skill up, how to level your characters so that they change into certain classes, how to make sure your members learn special abilities and how to manipulate union formations to give the biggest bonus stats. It's also very easy to skip quests and therefore miss important items or recruitable players without using the wiki as many quests become unavailable after certain story developments in the game. However, personally, I found it extremely rewarding to figure out everything and create the optimum setup for my team. It really depends on if you want to invest the time and effort.The start of the game is pretty slow, as combat is very repetitive until you unlock more skill types to give you a variety of battle options. Contrary to what a lot of people seem to say, you don't have to grind whatsoever. You have the ability to slow time, making it rather easy to avoid the monsters on the field, and as monsters scale with your level it can often make it more difficult to grind. The reason people think this is because some of the bosses are very hard, but you're supposed to change your union formations to suit the fight.The music is very atmospheric, particularly the battle music, though it can sometimes be a tiny bit repetitive if you play for long periods of time. The voice acting is very good and it adds a lot in the battle when the characters yell things out while they fight, but you probably want to keep it in Japanese with subtitles. The English ones aren't that bad, just a bit cheesy.The game is quite old but some of the graphics are still amazing to me. Everything is really detailed and has it's own atmosphere. Melphina is probably still one of my favorite cities in any game - just stand on the deck and stare out at the waterfall-thing. It also makes battles a lot cooler, when you're fighting huge dragons and they're all look gorgeous. It was very forward for it's time, and even now a lot of games don't do it as well. As it's a console port, using a controller is much more smooth, and it's easier to hit the buttons during fast-paced quicktime scenes in battles using one. And, as most people didn't seem to know, you can skip cutscenes by hitting Pause/Break (where the scroll lock and print screen buttons are) and then hitting S (Not sure if there are specific controller buttons for this).

												From Squeenix comes a fairly fun, non-traditional JRPG. The graphics, IMHO, are stunning, and the gameplay is simple enough to gain good control over if you simply pay attention to the tutorials that pop up when they are needed. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												I actually gave this game another chance after having given up on it the first time through. Although I enjoyed it a lot more the second time around I still can't recommend this game. From the game mechanics to the presentation, eveything feels very clunky and unpolished. Pros:* Combat:It's still very much a traditonal turn-based JRPG in terms of combat although instead of just ganging up on one unit, you'll 1v1 everybody in order to prevent flank attacks which do more damage. There's an illusion that you're actually moving around like a tactical RPG ala Fire Emblem, but that's not really the case. There's also a morale system where you deal more damage if the battle's going your way, but I'm not really a big fan of it as I feel it's unnecessary and clunky.* Crafting:You're able to dungeon dive and kill monsters for components so that you can create new weapons or upgrade old weapons. Cons:* Shoddy camera:It zooms in when you're trying to look up and zooms out when you try to look down. I like my camera to be at a set distance and this made me slightly nauseous at times as I'm constantly zooming in and out as I try to look at something.* Story:I liked the game far more after I skipped all the cutscenes and ignored whatever Rush (MC) was saying. The story is whatever but Rush is very cringeworthy. * Gameplay:The game doesn't explain itself very well and I had to look up things a couple of times just to figure out what was going on. Why are orders random? What's this status effect do? I uninstalled the game after a boss cursed all my units and randomly instant KOed them and I couldn't heal or revive anybody.* No Exploration:Everything is an instance/dungeon so you pick among a list of choices on a map and teleport into that area.* JargonPersonal pet peeve. Raidlock? Deadlock? Unions? Why use such weird terminlogy? Engage / disengage and Squads / Unit is much more natural sounding.

Go somewhere, save someone, introductoin of several new character, events, wars, political connections, ambitions, artifacts and so on. But the storytelling in this game is so pathetic that the old final fantasy games (even the first one) gave you more satisfaction from playing. Here you learn random information in such random order that grinding in this game is more fun that learning about the story. "Oh, your sisters was kidnapped? No worries i lend you ALL my generals to help you. I dont know you but what the hell " Screw  protection of the country(Those generals can fall to basic monsters, pathetic and illogical)"Oh, the academy took part in kidnapping? My god thats terrible"   What academy? Whos the leader? Why would i care?"Oh, your pendant glows in front of that guy that just disappeared into thin air?  Then drop everything and find him"  Why damn it? What is this pendant?"Oh, he bind himself to the "ark"?  Thats... bad?  What now? Oh, hes kind enough to unbind himself. So now we are happy?  Still dont know why'Npc's talk about some strange creature that was spotted in town. You meet this thing. "Oh wanna go with us? Cool" Npc's forgets about him.A character dies. You lost a party member but dont worry. Here is the child of this character that was passing by (you litteraly had no idea that this child exist) and can go with us instead of the dead one."Wanna talk about your dead parent? You dont give a fu***? Cool"Some major thing happend. Narration starts: "6 months later... the goverment dealt with the situation... yada yada" And what was happening with the main characters during this 6 months? Absolutly fu**** nothing. Move on with the story and dont ask anything if something is stupid.I would write something about the ending but its kinda hard to NOT spoil it (still stupid, random and not enough explanation)I LITERALLY fell asleep during playing.Battle system is original but is it fun? Im not sure. Kinda random. And slaying one character in a group of people kills them all cause they share the hp. Kinda stupid.  Audio is neutral. Nothing special.  Movement animation is sometimes pathetic. The great emperor of "some country" does something badass  and then he walks away like his sliding on the floor. Kills mood instantly.The overall feelings from the animation makes you think that you are playing Final Fantasy 12 (witch is a really good game) But as i said the movement of characters detroys evrythingIm not a hater. Still not worth buyingMaybe the way i wrote this review is a little chaotic but believe me, its nothing compared to this gamePeace

content:
, 2016
												I really tried to like this game as I'm running out of decent games to play...but I just can't finish it.The characters/writing are atrocious. Quests are horribly uninspired and are rarely more than "get to the end of the dungeon". The combat is unique at least, but I can't say that I enjoy it. It seems as if customisation is meant to be a huge part of the combat, but I'm ten hours in and haven't found any way to meaningfully to do so. Every enemy dies to the same combat arts spam. The fights themselves have the appearance of being tactical affairs, but it's RNG heavy. Sometimes one of your units gets focused by 4 enemies and dies, leaving you with a lost fight. Short of that, the same ganging up on enemy units is always the correct approach. (At least up to where I made it)It is an interesting idea of a game, but it completely falls short in all areas.

												basically only buy this if you're an experienced jrpg fanthe battle system is the strongest point of the game for me as its a really interesting mix of JRPG turn based combat with elements from strategy games. but i've also heard the exact opposite opinion from people who liked everything else in the game so much that they put up with the combat. so idk, maybe there's a little something in this game for everyone?the battle system is really fun and is full of a lot of interesting mechanics, but the game isn't exactly top notch at explaining it all. it took me 3/4ths of the game to feel like i completely understood the battle mechanics, and even then i found myself a little confused or frustrated at times. the battles sometimes feel very random but often times the only thing that decides the winner is your own strategypersonally i found the story to be really boring and unengaging, but not enough that it made me stop caring. there was interest in seeing where the story went, but i didn't feel like i really cared what happened. i just wanted to knowthe difficulty of the game is also skewed as ♥♥♥♥, there were boss battles that i had to retry over and over that were side by side with boss battles i felt were extremely underwhelming. maybe i was doing something very wrongalso 75% of the content of this game is sidequests. if that's your thing then cool but i found it very weird that there were entire cities and full dungeons that i wouldn't have known about if i hadn't stopped in at a town's pub. also a lot of the sidequests don't feel that special, it's often just going to a dungeon and getting to the "end" of it.i've said a lot of bad things about the game but it honestly is worth playing, especially at its price. i got a good 60 hours out of it and that's only with half the sidequests done. i really enjoyed creating parties and seeing what worked in battles and i really enjoyed the larger scale wars, even though there weren't too many. the story isn't that bad but i couldn't care less about the characters. idk. if you're big on rpgs with interesting battle systems i absolutely recommend this

content:
25, 2013
												The Last Remnant is a unique title.  It manages to have some of the greatest voices on the face of the planet and still manages to fall short due to its writing.  The main character is voiced by Johnny Yong Bosch, so you'd think he'd be able to save the performance, right?  Nope, the writing's that dry and cliched...though moreso the former than the latter.What does make this game worth recommending, however, is the gameplay.  When I say that the title is unique, I don't mean because of the writing; games have had great voices and bad writing before.  What makes this game unique is that it has a style of gameplay unseen since Chaos World back on the NES.  Rather than controlling one character at a time and fighting monsters that way, you take several characters into a fight and control them as squads.  This isn't a Turn-Based game, either, though it may look it...or not.  This game is the type of thing that is hard to decipher from videos alone, but its more of a Tactical Turn-Based RPG, though I wouldn't go as far as to call it a Strategy RPG.This game also lends itself to an OK story, but there's enough here to keep one who is having fun interested for a while.  The areas are large and open (and this is not a linear game), the customization is one of the more unique things I've seen out of an RPG, and the character recruitment process is slightly unpolished, among other things in the game, but the idea of having so many optional characters with histories and personalities is a nice touch.  If the price is low enough (and this game can go pretty low, price-wise) then I'd definitely recommend checking it out, especially if your looking for a unique experience.

content:
9, 2013
												This game is amazing! The first thing you need to understand is this game is the fixed version. If you look for reveiws online they all talk about the Xbox and Playstation versions that were all a buggy mess. When they ported to the PC they added in all the content from both consoles and fixed the bugs and glitches.I recommend using a controller for the game as well (though it does work with keyboard and mouse but I found it more enjoyable/easier for me personally to use a controller). I used an Xbox 360 controller (built-in support for it) and had no issues whatsoever.The difficulty of the game is counter to almost every other JRPG made. The difficulty increases as you grind and level up so you can technically beat the game at lvl1 faster/easier than at lvl99+. The combat is turn based/auto-resolve where the only control over the fights you have is setting up the units in the groups and telling what style you want the group to fight as (attack/assist/defend/etc).The game part way in unlocks the ability to slow/freeze time to allow you to "tag" enemies so you can chain groups to increase the drop chance of items and increase the xp you get (bonus for the more enemies you fight at once).There is a New Game+ ****BUT***** it's not your normal New Game+ Mode. Instead of having all the levels, items and units you unlocked before you start over from scratch with only some things carrying over.Things that carry over as copied from the wiki article (http://lastremnant.wikia.com/wiki/New_Game_Plus)    All components    All formations    All magazines    Your current customization levels    All items that unlock arts for Rush. Rush will also begin the new game with the first art of the skills granted to him by the Orbs and Formulas. For example, carrying over the Evocation-enabling Azure Orb will grant Rush the lowest-ranked Evocation, Mystic Missile, at the start of the game.    Mr. Diggs' skill levels and digs count    All area mapsSo when you are close to finishing the game (it'll be pretty clear as you'll be able to craft really good items) DON'T CRAFT ANYTHING AND FINISH THE GAME IF YOU PLAN ON PLAYING NEW GAME+!

content:
y 9, 2014
												Sick of hack n' slash action games posing as the real deal? This is a great way for PC gamers to play a turn-based, strategic RPG, which unfortunately, has been a dying genre for the platform since the 90s. I don't like that it eschews a world map (a terrible trend in Japanese RPGs). However, some of the areas are vast enough to give the feel of a world map, even if you are just picking names of places to go. This isn't as good as Final Fantasy XII, the only FF that wasn't garbage after IX, but it gets the job done. The battle system could have offered more control, but it adds a different kind of strategy with who to target, and when to use what commands you are given the option to use. The texture pop-in of the UT3 engine is bad, and the cutscenes look like crap even after forcing v sync with a third-party app, but the towns and the remnants look cool. There are also many sidequests, and you'll probably need to do a lot of them because the boss battles can be rough.

												I'm strangely fond of this game and I played it WAY later than when it came out. So those of you still waiting or wondering - this review might help you.Positive - Gorgeous graphics, many side quests, solid story and most characters are well developed, combat is challenging (this is also a negative at many points), decent humor. Voice acting is a net positive even if a couple characters are annoying. Non-linear. Great music. Long storyline, it will take you a while to complete.Negative - I personally found the weapon upgrade system confusing and got tired of trying to collect ingredients over and over. Sometimes the side quests just took too long - it's supposed to be a side quest, not a 1 hour journey through somewhere I've already been. Battle difficulty felt inconsistent and at times impossible - read FAQs and walkthroughs if you get stuck.I know my negative list is more verbose but bottom line, if you like JRPGs, you're going to like this one.

content:
16, 2015
												Overall, I give the game a "thumbs up", but it will ultimately split players based on its quirky leveling and combat system.  There are a couple other design decisions that I thought were odd, but they did not detract from my enjoyment of this title.  The core of this game is all about the fighting, and you will do a lot of it.  The battle system takes some getting used to.  First of all, your characters fight in small groups called unions.  As you progress through the game, you unlock more characters, formations, skills, etc.  The bit that takes some getting used to is that the player does not necessarily give orders to individual characters, but only to the unions.  For the most part I did not have any issues with this system once I got used to it.  However, there were times when I needed to heal up and that option just was not available.  It was also a little frustrating when my super skills that can be used by some of the main characters would not come up during boss battles but would come up while fighting some weak creature.  The game itself does a horrible job of giving any real details about this battle system.  So much is really out of the player's hands.  Other than giving high level commands to your unions, the actual skills that are performed are up to the individual characters and can change based on the situation.  This seemed to work fairly well other than a few critical times when I needed to heal up a downed union, but this will drive some players bonkers.  Another odd bit about the battle system is the area of the fight.  You get to decide which enemy union your unions will be fighting against.  Sounds great until you see that the positioning itself makes no real tactical sense.  AOE skills may completely miss or hit all the enemy unions.  Unfortunately, the player really has no control over specific placement.  The other major leveling portion is weapons and crafting.  There are literally hundreds and hundreds of components, upgrade materials, crafting elements, etc.  The actual inventory system is terrible.  Keep that WIKI handy as it is crucial to find that one oddly-named item you need to upgrade your weapon.  Your party characters will also ask for items at times and it is satisfying to see their weapons change from low level into deadly works of art later in the game.  Be aware that for some items you need to first have to complete a quest to get the ability to farm that needed item off of a monster.  Story is overall fairly good and kept me interested.  Know that my time with the core quest was only about a quarter to third of my gametime.  The rest was doing optional content and we aren't just talking about a couple of zones.  There are whole areas and cities which can be missed.  Even some party characters will give quests which can be satisfying.  Graphics during the fight scenes are excellent with fluid movements.  On the other hand, characters moved stiffly during some of the cutscenes.  Completionists can expect a lot to do with all of the items to upgrade and quests to complete.  Most of this is good, but one of the most annoying aspects of the game for me was trying to get certain monsters to spawn for certain guild quests.  Monsters in the various zones spawn off of a set table (check WIKI) and this includes rares.  The issue is having to zone to the overworld and then back again just to get the desired monster to spawn.  It really gets tedious when the needed monster is deep in a labrynth.  It just takes away from the whole immersion and it made some of my play sessions tedious.I realize I gave some negative items in the review above but for the most part I really liked this game.  I would strongly recommend the demo first so you can see for yourself if it is something you would want to spend 100+ hours on.

content:
r 5, 2014
												Rating: 6.5/10Overview: Turn Based JRPGThe Good:+In any JRPG you will spend the majority of time in combat, so it's important that you enjoy it or else you probably won't enjoy the game. Luckily this game has an enjoyable and strategic combat system. Rather than control single units you command groups of units called unions. You can have a max of 5 party members per union and a total of 18 party members. Thus one of the first strategic decisions you make is whether  or not you should have a few large unions or many smaller unions. Each one comes with its own pros and cons. Within each union you can also set the formation which also grants certain benefits and weaknesses. I.e Higher strength vs lower magic.  In combat each union is given a list of commands depending on which party members you grouped together. When you engage with an enemy union "deadlock" occurs. Deadlock means you have to kill the enemy union before you can target someone else. However, you can break deadlock to heal/revive another union, however this  will mean the enemy will get an extra attack. Thus, it becomes very important to only break deadlock when necessary. In addition to this, there is also flank attacks, rear attacks, interference/interceptions,...terms the game does a decent job of explaining.  Who you attack and how many unions you send to attack is a large part of the strategy involve. Do you gang up on a single enemy union causing more damage but leaves you more vulnerable to flank attacks or do you target multiple enemy unions and hopes your party is strong enough to handle each one? These are some of decision you make during some of the tougher battles.There is also a morale meter in combat. The more you kill enemy unions, flank attack, interfere, and in general the better you do in combat, the higher the morale. A higher morale means more damage given and less damage taken. Conversely, the better the enemy does the lower the moral meter. Lower morale means more damage taken and less given. During some of the easier battles, moral doesn't play that big of a role, but when you start fighting boss enemies it's important to keep the morale as high as possible as it could be the difference between surviving an attack or having an entire union wiped out in a single blow.   You put this all together and you have a fun, fast and engaging combat system that can easily hold up throughout the course of the game. + Turbo mode option doubles the speed of battle. A great feature that speeds up gameplay.  + An option that turns off quick time events in battle and makes them automatic. During battle there are times when you have QTE granting you higher damage.  Again, a great feature to have. The only downside to this is that it has roughly  80% success rate.  + The game auto saves after every battle and every time you enter an area. I know it's not exactly a big thing but this feature saved me a lot of trouble during the course of the game. +The game is filled with interesting locations and characters. Each city feels different based on the geographical location. The areas you explore are varied, from subterranean caverns, sandy deserts to forests and swamps. Artistically they all feel great and fun to explore. + The game is filled with plenty of side quests and optional areas. Completing many of these side quests allow you to hire specific characters for your party so it provides a good incentive for completing them. If you just stick to the main story you will probably miss over 50% of the game. +This is more than just a straight port to the PC. The game makes a variety of gameplay and balance changes throughout the entire game and Square-Enix should be commended for taking the time and effort to make the game better on PC. +Loved the musicThe Bad:-The biggest downside is the game does such a poor job of explaining some of the more important game mechanics. For example, the game gives a brief 2 line description about the type of formation you want to use but does not mention how specific of a bonus or weakness it will give your party. The game desperately needed an codex within the game detailing monsters and where to find items to upgrade your equipment. Having to go online to search for this information is an indication of poor design.   -One of the more important mechanics the game fails to explain is Battle Rank. As you win battles your Battle Rank goes up which is dependent on how many monsters you fight, how hard the battle is, how many unions died in battle etc. You would think the higher the Battle Rank the better your doing. In fact the higher the rank, the harder the enemies. If your Battle Rank grows higher than the rate in which your stats increase you could find the enemies very difficult to defeat and find yourself stuck. Granted, this is one feature they improved upon the PC version however it's still a problem and it is poorly explained in the game.  In theory, it is a good system to have to prevent grinding, however this system can also be exploited. - The game has some ludicrous difficulty spikes. I almost stopped playing the game early on because of how frustrating the battles became, especially boss battles.  Normally you can just can grind it out, however because of Battle Rank you have to be a bit more careful how you improve your stats. -I am not a fan of JRPG's stories and this game is no exception. The story feels stereotypical of all JRPG's before it. The dialogue is embarrassingly bad and the voice acting is just as terrible. The characters are one dimensional and the main character is annoying. -Significant texture pop in. ConclusionI enjoyed the game but its flaws really dragged the game down. What should have been a more enjoyable experience ultimately felt more frustrating. Despite the  score I still recommend the game because if you like JRPGs and like learning new game systems  and getting really immersed in the game this is a game you should check out. Everybody else should expect an average JRPG.

It is not optimized for the PC.I have been to forums, trying out every suggestion to make the video and graphics better, as it should be since this is a 2009 game and my rig, though not the most powerful, still can hold its own.I have tried every graphics setting all the way down to low and none. I've lowered resolution to 1280x720. It improves performance, but only slightly.Slightly.My gosh, I mean seriously, there have been guys in forums stating that their rigs can run CRYSIS 1 and 2 fully maximized everything, and this game makes their gaming rigs cry uncle.What gives?I have one last trick that I can try. I will install this in my SSD hard drive. Hopefully it will make this game run silky smooth. But I'm not confident, as I have played another port (ENSLAVED: Odyssey to the West) in my SSD and I had cutscene loading problems.I guess its true, what they say - ports from consoles suck eggs 95% of the time.I want to like this game. Seriously, I do. I'm even willing to do the research in the wikis necessary to be able to play it the smart way. Its just dumbed down by technical reasons. Too bad.UPDATE: Keep ALL video and graphics settings to DEFAULT VALUES and it should run silky smooth. With this info, I change my recommendation from NOT Recommended to Recommended.Wooohooo!!!! Time to enjoy some Japanese RPG!

content:
16, 2014
												Yes, buy and play this game. It goes on sale frequently. You can choose to quickly play through just the main plot or go for a very long, full completion.While I doubt that it was their intention to write their main character as so annoying as to drag the whole quality of the game down, I feel like the real complaint from detractors of this game is that the main character isn't socially normalized enough. I've met several people like the main character, though: loud, don't think deeply, altruistic, and self-censoring (re: "Let's kick some A!"). I'd rather sit through an awkward character's screen time in the context of an engaging story than have a really targeted and over-designed main character whose only flaw is that they're too awesome for the world they exist in (ugh, it must be so hard for them).This game has a story that takes you through individual character storylines with quests that help provide cohesion if you let it, but, and this is the uniquely good part, you have the option to skip all of that. Just like you have the option to skip tactics and decision-making in combat, even going so far as to publicly write it off as wholly random or even just containing "too much" randomness. With the exception of the scenario of "I want to choose exactly what every unit of every union in my army does at every moment", other players' experience (first-hand knowledge of how the game's mechanics work together) demonstrates that there is actually a level of control you can achieve that approaches that but ultimately settles on a medium somewhere between the micro-managerial staple of other RPG games and no control. For me, I don't like the part of old-school RPGs where it's basically button mashing through a ton of menus with no risk of losing a fight. I like this game's system so much better because it only ever approaches that if you're fighting enemies that you seriously out-rank, and the game does a great job of providing difficult areas (an unlockable tiered end-game area) and monsters (they scale up).Furthermore, the main character being annoying has no bearing on the unravelling of the Conqueror's plans (It wasn't about conquering anything. It was about liberating all remnants.), the development of Athlum's independence, the fantastic descent into greed-fueled madness of Duke Hermeien, and the tragic storyline of the Conqueror's Seven. And, that's only the content from the non-missable plot in this game. In the missable plot, you get to meet and redeem those seven characters from the tight grip of the Conqueror's mythology and power.Now, does the game fall into tons of stereotypical jRPG story elements (re: tropes)? Undeniably. It includes mechas (Hermeien), main character amnesia, direct replacement characters (Emma), an every-man with a super-power (Rush), parents who are completely out of the picture of their young children's lives, a bizarre sense of fashion that tries to differentiate major characters without building towards some larger narrative, and a mascot (re: Mr. Digg) who looks like nothing else in the whole game. Are they really out of place in this game, though? I don't think so. If Rush's Talisman made him transform into a Remnant Monster (reminiscent of something mechanized), I probably would have felt it crossed the line into tripe. Or, if Emma and Emmy's characters had zero difference (other than the name).The game's best moments for me were near the end of the game when you can hear the many different voices of your characters in battle modified by the barely positive morale of that battle, signifying that you're on par with your enemies, making you realize you've amassed and trained a small army of awesome companions.In conclusion, if an "Everyone's getting hyped!" is good and a "They caught us with our pants down!" is bad, then I give this game a grade of: "IRIIIIIIIIIIIINAAAAAAAAA!"

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 23, 2014
												"7.0/10"+ Rich graphics, memorable symphony music, unique/massive scale fights- Zero character growth, battle commands are random, sidequests are grindfestsA beautiful mechanically sound game that brings in an interesting battle system into an otherwise predictable jrpg plot. The Last Remnant caught my eye from the get-go with its visuals but dulled me back to real life with its  nuanse of storytelling and smaller-than-it-looks worlds. You play as Rush, a stubborn and small-minded individual out to save his sister and the world from destruction (How different!). What saves the narrative is a union-based system that gives you a commander-shouting experience. Rather than control each member, you're giving directions to the union as a whole and letting them decide. It gives the game a unique flair and really, Steam should list "Strategy" as its 2nd or 3rd tag. Without a proper setup; having a healer, disabler, tank, area of effect abilities, you'll be left scratching your head, getting smashed from some of the more formidable story bosses. Thankfully Steam gives you an emulator-esque experience, letting you save at any point in the game as long as you're not presently in a battle. This means you can rewind and plan accordingly. Thin your numbers out with more unions and flank the enemy? Bolster two-three unions for a direct assault? Focus on moral boosting units and leader special abilities? Acquiring more party members is also a treat as you'll be entering towns and recruiting people from various guilds. Getting the better party members requires you to do sidequests... and boy are some of them lengthy. Despite an engaging battle system that keeps you interested, it also has flaws. For one the commands are random. If you want a unit to do something specific, chances are it may not show up. Heal this union? No, sorry, I'll heal this other one. Use our special union ability even though we have enough mana? Maybe next turn. It's discouraging as well as prolongs otherwise 20-30 seconds fights into 2-3 minute charades. Buy:  For the gameplayDon't buy: For the plot

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 30, 2014
												I absolutely love this game and stand by it. I have put probably about 300-400 hours into this game (not on steam, but mostly on xbox). I bought it on PC because it is a superior version which does allow more specific choices for characters and doesn't punish you for grinding.I Think the battle system and character progression system is great, but not for everybpdy. Your characters will grow depending on the commands you give in battle, the commands you get to choose from in battle are limited, but are always swayed by the choices you have made for that group of characters previously. Instead of having 6 focused characters, which you make specific choices for growth, like in the usual JRPG fare, you have 20 characters and make general choices in combat that indirectly affect the character's growth. It means that all the choices you make will have an impact, so you have to be mindful of what abilities you want a group to have.The battles are both challenging and engaging and unlike other JRPGs I've played. The fact they are large scale is really enjoyable, and you can also speed past them if you'd like. If you really want to enjoy it, you will need to use the wiki for it. There are details which appear as random in this game, but are really a number of complex factors that create a coherent, if unclear, system.The game's content is mostly sidequests and completely optional, and are amongst the most rewarding challenges I have faced in most JRPGs. I always feel like there is more I could do and more progression I could make, creating powerful and interesting combinations of characters.I thik this title is greatly misunderstood and underrated because of the sub-par Xbox release, but is really a unique JRPG gem and will shine through if you have the time and interest.
