16, 2014
												I got this game on a whim during a sale, because strictly speaking Square Enix owns at least 1/3 of my soul. I wasn't overly disappointed with TLR. The graphics and controls are pretty top=notch for the game's age, and the difficulty scales well. I did have problems with some tougher bosses based on hiring new units and the way the 'leveling' system works. (Some of my units were woefully underpowered for several fights.) That said, the combat system (controlling several parties) is intriguing, and I'd like to see SE revisit it with a little more traditional RPG leveling system in mind. My only true gripe about this game is something that ALL developers need to take to heart: Skippable. Cutscenes. Even in NG+, the cutscenes are unskippable, and they are LONG. Have popcorn while playing. Overall, I'd give this game a 7/10. Cutscenes notwithstanding, the story can feel a little forced at times, and sometimes hard to follow, and honestly a little boring at points. The combat and gameplay in general are good enough to play through at least once.

content:
17, 2015
												This is an intricate game that is a lot of fun to play, and rewards the careful planner and strategist.  Union formation requires planning beforehand, but is still quite versatile with plenty of options.  Each turn in battle requires careful consideration.  The battles are challenging but enjoyable (for the most part).  Outside of battles, there's plenty to keep a completionist player occupied: sidequesting, collecting, crafting, guild tasks, fighting rare monsters and superbosses.  There's a bit of everything here, and I think The Last Remnant puts it together quite well.The main storyline is serviceable but nothing spectacular.  The party members (ie. leaders) are a nice variety with their own distinct stories and related quests.  The cinematics are pretty, but voice-acting could definitely be better.  I'm usually big for a good story, but I was too busy crafting, questing, etc, to notice how ordinary this story was.I didn't find it too hard to pick up and grasp the basics of the battle system, and I think you can play the game without needing the Wikia website.  But there's so much content and detail that is easy to miss, and if you're a completionist like me, you'd want to use the Wikia.Apart from battles and following the main campaign, I had a lot of fun just running around, looking at things, exploring the world.  I recommend The Last Remnant if you like a TBS that rewards careful planning before and during a battle.

												This game is an amazing JRPG with a quite unique combat and leveling system, and it was released on PC in a time when there wasn't that many JRPGs on the platform. Combat can get tedious but it's so fun to level your units the correct way and do all the side quests and such. Sound effects and music is AAA qualityConclusion: 9/10 , one of the best JRPGs on PC. I'd even go so far to say this is better than FF 13 series.  If you see this in a sale and you like JRPGs, pick it up ASAP.

content:
er 28, 2013
												The Last Remnant is a role playing that has you taking charge of large groups of soldiers as you fight to protect your kingdom from the threat of the Conqueror.The game is split between a world area, a battle area, and a world map, you control Rush Sykes the protagonist and move him about the world and then use the made too outside of different areas.In battle you control squads made up of different fighters starting off with being only able to employ a few in each group as you start off you then can build massive armies by the middle of the game mixing in with all sorts of different skills you also gain unique characters too by doing missions or buying them and guilds each one able to be upgraded by finding materials in the area’s you visitThe combat is straight forward selecting from Combat Art (physical attacks) and Mystic Art (magic) mixing these into your group and even having a few groups the specialise in these area are always good. I do find combat can get a little hard but once you figure out which combination of group’s works and what tactics to give them then you’ll have to problems mowing down your enemiesYou can also undertake side quests too that help keep a good length in the game and will help you gain more party members and gear.With the combat being a little confusing and hard it is easy to give up on the game after a couple of loses but if you stick with it this a good game to get through and will leave you some satisfaction once beat those hard boss fights i give this 7 out 10

content:
2, 2011
												Probably one of the most fun RPGs by Square in a long time. It's a shame it (rather unfairly) reviewed so poorly because it's certainly a lot better than the by-the-book rubbish in the FF series. Battles consist of you vaguely controlling multiple groups of characters, rather than 3-5 guys directly. the screenshots of battle show it nicely - you pick general orders for each group at the start of each turn and the individual units decide what the best moves to use are. The battles are also incredibly slick and very quick - don't expect to have to wait 42602 years for animations ala other RPGS; you'll get through a turn of 25 characters in as many seconds.  Story isn't great but is it ever from japanese RPGs? It's just really good fun and well polished, fast-paced group combat with a lot of customisation. Although the PC version is much better than the 360 one, it's best played with a 360 pad.

content:
11, 2016
												Since this is my first review of a game, please give me some leeway for a bit of naivety. It will happen, I'm sure, because I probably have bias towards or against some things in the game. Now to get on with the actual review.The Last Remnant is a game that I was skeptical about picking up at first. It happened to be on sale for $5, and I saw a few good reviews, so I decided to buy it, and I am so very glad I did. I love strategy games, and this turned out to be one of my favorite strategy games I had ever played, quickly knocking others down on my list.First, the story: in terms of details, it's pretty good; ideas, the same description; in fact, it has a rather unexpectedly in-depth story for what I expected, as of some of SE's games recently (I looked at a few; the story in each drove me away). It takes you into the world and explores the Remnants, which are mystical/magical objects that randomly appeared out of nowhere on the planet and, when bound, can be used as anything from a weapon to a tool and just about everything in-between. However, this is just a subsection of the story, which has (as far as I have played) covered politics, war, rogue elements, many details on the Remnants, scientific researchers, and i actually forgot the end of the list because there were enough parts that I ran out of attention span while typing this. It can be a bit wild in progression, as the story-based events occur only when you go to the right areas, but the quests and tasks (which are basically the normal "side quests" and "fulfill-and-reward" ideas) also add to the information on the world. A few quests even explore personal areas on certain characters, and each character that is involved in at least a side quest has been carefully built. I was very impressed by all of these details, and from what I have read, I'm not even halfway through the game.Next, the gameplay. Okay, so the first thing I'm going to say is this: there are way too many controls. Your battle controls, field controls, menu controls, and critical controls are many, and some of them overlap in weird ways. For instance, it appears that this game was set up to be used on controller, as you control sight/movement in the field with what is the keyboard equivalent of thumbsticks. Also, what you would think are the same controls in each area of the game are not. They may be bound to different things, i.e. camera movement controls in the field are camera/menu controls in battle (which, it is weird to move the menu and catch sight of your view moving in the same direction as your menu cursor) and a few other things. However, they are not impossible, and once you settle on a comfortable set for you, it doesn't take long before the controls seem natural, no matter how mixed up they seem at first. Now that I'm finished bugging out about that, let's move on to the rest of the gameplay. The Last Remnant uses a combat system that is unique in that I can't remember another game like it. I'm sure there was, but I'm at a loss to which it is. Anyways, you control unions (groups of fighters assembled before battle in preset positions) in a tactical battle setting, which is to say that although you take turns, where you wanted to go and what you wanted to do with each union may not happen. In the battle, unions move throughout the field and engage enemy unions in various forms. You also have to deal with morale, which increases and decreases according to your success in battle. I'll leave it to the game for an explanation, but suffice to say that it is an interesting fight, and no two engagements seem the same.Now, on to other details. The music is quite good; a heavy beat gets you pumped for a fight, and the music changes depending on morale during battles, which in my case either sent me on a murderous rampage or had me fighting desperately for my life. It grabs you and drags you into the fight like no other music I've heard before, similar to the way that the Final Fantasy series often did in the past (case in point: 4-7, at least in my opinion). The characters develop a lot more than I suspected they would. I thought they would be plain soldiers with backgrounds and a bit of development, but they also develop some of the characters you get from sidequests, giving them background information, personalities, and putting much  emotion into the way they act. I find that I absolutely hate to lose units in battle, not just because they are useful, but also due to the emotions and their personalities that have burnt themselves into my mind and heart, and losing one means I lost a friend in the game. When that happens, well, take how you would feel if someone KO'ed your friend with a punch to the face when you were right there with them and apply it to the situation. That's my personal twist on the characters in the game, and I don't care whether you think I'm insane or not (I am, by the way :} ).In conclusion, the story is pretty good, the music is epic, the battles are engaging, and the only cons you really have to deal with are the occasional slowdown at the start of a cutscene (due to high processing required and extreme details being applied, has occurred few enough times that I can count them on my hands) and the exceedingly rare random close out (happened a grand total of 3 times for me so far, two of them I'm pretty sure were because my computer was doing updates, the warning and the actual restart caused the game to close out). In my humble opinion, this game is 10/10. I love it, am addicted to it, and will never say otherwise. ^_^

content:
, 2016
												The Last Remnant has been one of the few games which I can replay and experience it differently even though the story is the same (bar one set side quest options). I originally played this game on the Xbox 360 so I'm used to the game mechanics, however I have to play with a controller on this steam version as the controls for the keyboard are difficult in comparison as the buttons aren't as straight-forward. The game doesn't have steam achievements.Game: Overall, the plot of the game is pretty straight forward as you get reminded or can talk to NPCs to tell you what you need to do. After completing several story points, you are almost able to fully explore the world from near the start of the story, adventuring through the different areas and unlocking other towns. Some are mandatory for the story to progress but others are optional. Side quests pop up after most story events, so revisiting towns and cities are a must if you want to complete them all.Battle System:This is a hit or miss for everyone. I know plenty of people who dislike the battle system due to controlling a union of people but not being able to control each and every single unit. At first it is confusing as not many games use this style but after getting to grips with it, it is extremely useful and conserves time. Since it's a turn based game, imputting the attacks takes long enough to decide as unions so it's literally a godsend that we don't control each character exactly. The camera angles of the fighting keeps you involved in the fight as it follows those whose turn it is attacking/supporting/on standby. Another way this game involves you is by using a critical trigger. It requires you to press the button when the ring encloses over it. By doing so, not only do you bump up your allies in the turn system but also improve the critical chance of your attacks as well as a chance of synergising the last allies attack to a better one if you have enough Action Points(AP). Battles have frontal attacks (deadlocks), side attacks (flanks) and rear assaults which can give your parties edge in a battle but enemies also have the ability to do the same.Unions:You can choose who you want in your party by either completing their missions and buy there services in the guild or talking to one of the soldiers in Athlum (when you are given permission). Certain characters are required for side quests to appear. Unions are made up of a maximum of 5 units. These units/people are chosen by you and can be arranged in different formations to suit their opponents or roles before battle. Different formations have different abilities, strengths and weaknesses so it's fun to play about with what works best. Apart from your character/Rush Sykes, you aren't able to equip other units personally, if you have a weapon and they want it, they'll ask in the map screen if they can take it off your hands. However, they also ask for materials to improve their weapons as well so hunting items down is a good way to increase the strength of your parties. The stats in the game aren't really explained about, neither are class roles but are mostly straightforward apart from their trait stats.Skills: There are multiple arts which can be learnt such as combat, magicks, lotions etc. When learning specific ones, you are able to disable the use of other skills, enabling the one you want to learn more likely to pop up as an option in battle. I've seen a lot of people say the moves all look the same but I disagree with this. Sure, some have the same energy build up but the actual attack performed is different in some way.Visuals & Sound: Originally on the 360, my game was glitchy and laggy most the time. The steam version is much better, there are still glitches at times (like capes spinning about) but the smoothness of the animation at full visual capacity is quite good for a 2008 made game. The detail can take a few seconds to load in though. The voice acting for the game is okay, not the best voice acting but also not the worst. I'm a sucker for Square Enix soundtracks, so the music accompaning the game is quite beautiful and helps set the situation of the game. Within battle, the music can change depending on moral, turns or how close a union is to dying.Other notes: Sovani. Are. Awesome.

content:
, 2016
												Good game with very poor PC controls. Not only is everything designed for console but the PC controls are very unintuitive and annoying.  But...If you can look past that and the somewhat lacklustre story with too many cut scenes constantly interrupting gameplay. there's a good and deep RPG here. You ednd up commanding a full squad worth of people and the combat mechanics while they initially start out pretty simple get interesting towards the middle game. There's kind of an Elder Scrolls like element to the leveling up process. Your people learn based on what skills you tell them to use so you can make any character into any class (but some will be bad at it due to attributes).  This does have a drawback though of making combat pretty rep[etitive as you will be constantly wanting your troops to practice the same skills over and over to level them up.So yeah I'd put this in the good concept, flawed execution category but it's still worth playing if these kind of RPGs appeal to you at all.

												Probably one of the best games I have played. The combat system is fairly unique and can take a little bit of getting used to but once you understand how it works it is absolutely the most polished and exciting combat system in any jrpg. The story is kind of cliched in parts but it is fairly engaging and the depth of the side quest, upgrade, and weapons systems is better done than many. That said it is a jrpg, you will grind, you fight unfair battles that will make you want to kill all living things within reach and you will forget to do something important that will stunt one characters growth in game but it is all worthwhile. I would be remiss in not recommending this game (on pc) to all who enjoy a good game that can suck you in for hours at a time.

												I played for 6.5 hours straight in the first sitting which is rare since I've gotten to the point where I have so many games if I don't immediately love it I try something else.Combat seems simple but gains complexity, lots of characters, you can gather materials for upgrading, side quests, open world exploring, and rare monsters to find.  Story doesn't seem bad either.  Gives me a FF12/FFX vibe.Definitely recommend for anyone who likes FF or JRPGs.Edit: After quite a bit more playtime I wanted to mention this game is very hard at parts and its not obvious how to improve your party.  You have a 'battle rank' but that isn't equivalent to a level.  Someone BR 65 can struggle at the same parts as a BR 30.  A lot of the boss fights come down to simple luck if you get your random 'special skill' or not.  When the game gives you a warning that you won't be able to leave if you save somewhere make sure to use a new save slot.

												It is a fun game. it has a weird leveling and combat system that i say would turn off people who are more used to more popular RPGs like final fantasy and while it has a nice story, the pacing is a bit off to me and not very fluid. However, the combat system is very unique and can lead to various gameplays and strategies. for a 2009 game, the graphics are very good (but then again, graphics never really matters to me). i never played the xbox version but it has been said that the PC version is a lot better.the bad thing about this game is that they basically don't tell you about anything other than how to fight enemies. it has so much more than that like the upgrading and the leveling system. that leads to people, like me, to resort to outside help like wikis to play them or people just quitting the whole game because they cant figure anything out. if you play blindly and succeed, then i salute you. all in all, i would love to see more of the world and its people and its battle and leveling system expanded. i recommend the game for people who love turn-based RPGs, nice character design, great lore and/or strategy in RPGs (which i would say in a turn-based non-SRPG games are pretty rare). although this is a minor point, i would not recommend the game for people who like to control their party members individually as the battle system can get pretty random unless you set up correctly and for people who cannot stand the phrase "LET'S DO THIS!!!!"7.5/10

												With all it's flaws, this game is still one of my top 5 favourites. First of all it's challenging. If you are doing a full gameplay with all side quests and all, it will take an effort to get to the end. You MIGHT have to grind but I didn't feel it necessary. And even if I wanted to grind a little, and I didn't want to waste too much time, I sped the battle up, and it wasn't such a painful experience.Second of all the characters are awesome. They are all unique, with different characteristics and reasons to fight. I found it really nice that I could choose who to play with. And a lot of them have a special ability which one might consider to get, since it will not only look awesome but it also helps in battle. Just look up the wiki and see how many unique and special characters and abilities this game has. One can't even get every one of it by playing through once!No matter if the story is linear or the desert is so f*cking big that it takes half an hour to walk from one side to the other. You will probably never spend there that much time anyway. When I finished the game and it told me that I can  actually replay the whole, I was sure that I will visit this world again, and this time I make it count that I get every little secret it has in store for me.All in all it's an amazing game. Play it if you are up for the challenge and would like to hear a story about the magnificent world of Remnants!

content:
er 18, 2014
												It's probably worth my while mentioning the reason I first purchased this game (on Xbox, originally): some of the best slash writers in my reading list were writing really interesting stuff about the characters, and I wanted to get the original context.  Basically, this game is best played for the story and the interplay between the characters.  The animation, frankly, is as clunky as all get-out - it's best played after playing something like Final Fantasy VII or VIII (the original PS versions if you can get them) as something of a palate cleanser if you're a real graphics junkie (or you could go the whole hog and just play Angband or a similar text-based RPG as a starter).  The battle system is different - it's turn-based (as with the Final Fantasy and Dragon Quest series), but instead of making decisions about each individual fighter's actions, you're issuing commands to groups of fighters (and they will perform their actions based on your command).  You don't get access to every possible command - instead, you're choosing from a limited list - between six to eight options most of the time, narrowing down to about two or three when things get really nasty.  If you're a gameplay or a graphics fan, this probably isn't the game for you.If, like me, you're interested in story and worldbuilding, however, this game is *brilliant*.  The world is complex and well-realised, and it's fun to be sitting down and figuring out the back-story and the background politics.  The story is fascinating, and if you're a slash fan, it is a hoot how slashtastic the interaction between Rush and David (pronounced Dah-veed) turns out to be at times - and the slashtastic moments start very early on in the game.  The art is marvellously detailed, the backgrounds are glorious, and the characters are wonderfully created.  In many ways, I get the sense they spent so much time and effort on creating the story and the artwork that when it came time to add the animation and the gameplay, they'd almost run through the budget.  This resulted in very unrealistic movement (it's almost as though their animation models were puppets on strings - it is *very* Thunderbirds movement at times) and a lot of skimped details in the FMV scenes (the one which sticks in my head is one scene where Rush is sitting on a bed... and because the bed isn't animated at all, it stays a rigid rectangular shape.  All I could think is "that has to be hell on the back").It's almost a pity, in a way, they didn't put the same amount of time and effort into animating their artwork that they did into crafting it.  The voice actors do their best (although if you're familiar with British accents at all, you'll notice Lord David's accent keeps sneaking off toward Sarf Lunnon when he isn't watching) but really, given they're trying to effectively make wooden dolls live, their best has a limited effect.  As I said earlier: if you really need good animation and good gameplay to make a storyline live for you, this probably isn't the game for you.  If, on the other hand, you're a big fan of complex worldbuilding, interesting characters, and a fascinating plot, you'll probably be able to find enjoyment in the game despite the rather wooden movement.

content:
y 24, 2016
												2 technical issues   1)  Volume  controls do not affect the main page. Every time you start the game, every time you have to get to a load screen the music volume will goes up to its 100% until you make a selection. Gets tedious if you Play while others sleep.  2) Having software loaded for a n52te would not let the game grab control of the 360 controller. I have no idea why and it did not matter if i unplugged and restarted the pc, It would not recognize the controller until I removed the software.As far as gamplay goes it is pretty nice. Not a lot is explained up front, but there is a manual to look at to help you get started (if you prefer to just dive in without websites and guides). I did manage to pick up things pretty quickly from the mini tutorial at the start. Keyboard controls do not seem instinctive to me but that could be from my preference for the belkin over the past few years. But it plays very well with a controller. I'm not very far into the game yet. But I find the experience pretty fun. The most noteworthy being a completely random crit styled system that comes from the Gunblade (final fantasy 8) crits from pulling the trigger at the right time. In this game the function is expanded on to give multiple buttons (ABXY & right trigger). Except the queue is visual not auditory. You control group behavior not each individual in the group though with 5 options and the ability to see who will do what with each option before confirming you can somewhat affect how the move will go.  The main theme in fights seems to be to not let your party get surrounded. So be aware of that when you start early on if you attack middle groups you may find yourself making fights difficult for no good reason.

content:
4, 2015
												If you are a fan of the Final Fantasy style games and wanted to play them on a larger scale, then this is the game for you.You play a guy who's sister has been kidnapped near a large war. As you help the prince in his battles he tries to help you find your missing sister. A simple plot with a good amount of storyline for several of the party members.The game has you form groups to go into battle. On your turn, each group can do one type of move. The number of people in that group will each do that move if the have it available. If not, they will just sit there. Also, if the leader of the group is incapacitated the group cannot do any actions.In the beginning the battles seem pretty small and not worth it. As you get further in and Flanking and Intercepting are utilized more, it becomes a very good RPG mixed with strategy. You caan easily go from winning to utter failure if flanked. The graphics are quite good. Nothing to special but definitely not bad. There are several special moves "Summon style" that will shake things up a bit. They cannot be called at will so you have to plan accordingly.The thing that sucks about this game is the fact that you do not have all your skills available during the fight. Depending on how much AP you have, where you are in the battle, what the status of the groups, and whether you are flanking/flanked. will determine what pops up for you to chose from. Meaning your healers may not even have the heal option show up right when you need it or as a pre-emptive tactic.The game is long and the fights get longer. There are several special creatures that are very difficult to defeat.

er 25, 2012
												This is a surprisingly good XBOX360 port! I would strongly encourage a controller, unfortunately for those of us who'd rather just have some nicely adjusted controls, but it's pretty hard to do without. That said, the game itself has a delightfully interesting cast of characters - not just all boring animu girls and boys, believe it or not! The combat is rather unique and takes some getting used to, but is really quite interesting and fairly deep and complex - there are quite a few fan sites out there, so don't hesitate to read up a bit so you can get a good grasp of it. Altogether I would actually recommend this, as much as ports are usually lackluster at best. It runs great, plays well, and is a solid RPG.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
3, 2011
												TLR feels like a classic Square RPG between the Final Fantasy 6 and 7 era; at least as far as story and world goes. Take a completely fantastical storyline, a slightly irritating yet identifiable character, a supporting cast of twisted backstories and unusual concepts, and throw in some menu-based face smashing with just enough strategy to keep you scratching your head. It's a game that's 50% story and 50% bursts of strategic challenge in the form of difficult boss fights.My only complaint is that, like any typical CRPG-like, the grind through the dungeons can get tiring, but the story is well worth it.The system is unique, favoring macro strategy over micro. Your control over your party is limited to who you attack and how, but the choice of which specific attacks, battle order, and timing comes down to the AI and stats. This sounds boring but is actually engaging and uniqueIn the end TLR feels like a lovechild of Tactics, Final Fantasy 6 and 7, and Ogre Battle. Not a bad thing.

content:
er 1, 2010
												Un excellent RPG des maitres du genre sur console Square Enix. Un produit rare sur PC, qui joint RPG et tactiques pour fournir de grand moment de plaisirs.Great J-RPG game by Square-Enix.The story got some nice elements - there also a few cliché and some of the usual plot twists - but the overall is great.The game has some tactical and stragegic choice as you not only lv up the member of your team, but you must chose which skill learn for each of them - the more you learn, the slower they progress, so the less action of that skill you learn.You need to chose for them their behavior (simple A/B/C choice when they grow their weapon) by improving their weapon - which require component to loot (mobs / reward / digging).But the most important part is the squadron. You have a limited number of characters to deploy on battle - and a maximum number of squad. Up to you to decide the number of character per squad (up to his maximum) as well as the squad formation and where the member are in each squad formation.As each formation have pro and cons, it's important to know when to use one.Plus you don't chose your squad action as you like. The actions avaible is a guidline determined by the computer depending on the squad Action point, his member skills, his HP/ buff / debuff (as well as the other's squad) and his position on the map compared to the friend / enemy squad.Add special "limit break" skill, pincer attack and a gestion of moral squad by squad as well as team by team affection your action and their succes, and battle can get quite interesting.Sadly, as most JRPG, you got a lot of grinding and hidden quest.The good point is : the hidden quest (who are often harder than the main quest, especially at the end of the game) are the only one really needing grinding and providing real hard fight. But they gave overpowering reward.All in all, if you like JRPG, don't miss it (it could do with an HD version by now, true)

content:
, 2011
												This game is an amazing JRPG with a quite unique combat and leveling system, and it was released on PC in a time when there wasn't that many JRPGs on the platform. I haven't really put the hours into the PC version, did finish it will every achivement on the Xbox 360 back in the days. Graphics: Unreal engine makes this game look beutiful and the character models and monsters look real good, some enviroments look a bit "cheap" but a game thats now 7 years old it looks sweet.Story: A bit ditzy and hard to follow at times but it's pretty standard JRPG stuff in hereGameplay: I love it. Combat can get tedious but it's so fun to level your units the correct way and do all the side quests and such. Thats why I play JRPGs , for all the things around the main game :)Sound: Voiceacting on most important conversations and a lot of the voices are fitting for the characters. Sound effects and music is AAA qualityConclusion: 9/10 , one of the best JRPGs on PC. I'd even go so far to say this is better than FF 13 series.  If you see this in a sale and you like JRPGs, pick it up ASAP.

8, 2014
												Absolutely amazing game! The art style is almost a complete replica of the art style of Final Fantasy 12. Although the way you can avoid battling monsters in the game is similar to FF12, the combat system once in  battle is entirely different. Even if you buff up a single character's damage as much as possible, you can still be royally beaten to death. Strategy is a must in the battles. Flanking systems, methods of offense instead of straight skills, and random during-attack extra damage inducing button input all are brought to this new game. Spent 12 straight hours playing it for the first time. Although the combat system is a bit confusing at first, you figure it out relatively quickly over the countless battles you'll be put into. 100% worth the buy and play.

er 28, 2013
												The Last Remnant is a role playing that has you taking charge of large groups of soldiers as you fight to protect your kingdom from the threat of the Conqueror.The game is split between a world area, a battle area, and a world map, you control Rush Sykes the protagonist and move him about the world and then use the made too outside of different areas.In battle you control squads made up of different fighters starting off with being only able to employ a few in each group as you start off you then can build massive armies by the middle of the game mixing in with all sorts of different skills you also gain unique characters too by doing missions or buying them and guilds each one able to be upgraded by finding materials in the area’s you visitThe combat is straight forward selecting from Combat Art (physical attacks) and Mystic Art (magic) mixing these into your group and even having a few groups the specialise in these area are always good. I do find combat can get a little hard but once you figure out which combination of group’s works and what tactics to give them then you’ll have to problems mowing down your enemiesYou can also undertake side quests too that help keep a good length in the game and will help you gain more party members and gear.With the combat being a little confusing and hard it is easy to give up on the game after a couple of loses but if you stick with it this a good game to get through and will leave you some satisfaction once beat those hard boss fights i give this 7 out 10

content:
ry 20, 2014
												I was thoroughly surprised, and pleased, with The Last Remnant!After launching it a few times and barely making it an hour into the game, I gave up.Finally, I buckled down, desperate to beat boredom, and BEHOLD! An incredible game was discovered!If you do not initially enjoy The Last Remnant, stick with it.The first few fights make the combat seem chaotic and meaningless. In reality, it is very challenging, strategic, and rewarding. This expands greatly once you have access to Unions (or party formations).The game also bolsters many RPG elements I consider requirements;Item farming, crafting, upgrading gear, resource harvesting, rare boss monsters, many side quests, and a deep class system.All-in-all, I am incredibly pleased with the game (despite a bit of poor dialogue, here and there), and think it is a must play for my fellow JRPG gamers!

												This game is surprisingly good. For an RPG game its a well thought out game with all its features and battle system. If you want a game to spend many hours into it then look no further; it took me over 70 hours to beat this game for the first time and that's leaving a good chunk of the side missions left untouched. Picked this game up when steam had it on sale for $10 making it a great deal. Battle system took a little bit to get used to. But once you play enough you will get used to it, and it is nice being able to initaite encounters rather than random encounters happening as soon as you take a few steps. So yeah good game, story isn't too bad but it could have been so much better I think. Yay for being able to have Japanese voices with subtitles as an option! If you have an xbox ccontroller you can use that and it would probably be a little more comfortable than using the keyboard, oh and if you don't be sure to change  the settings to keyboard buttons!

content:
14, 2015
												I'm sad that this game didn't get the love it deserved at release, to few buyers to continue the series. But it might change if gets viral. 10$ this is a damn ripoff, deserves way more like when I paid 49$ around release.Bought it around 2010 and my PC could barely handle it at max. Graphically still amazing to this day, and you can even get a EMB Mod to enhance it even more.Story - Decent, but that's not what you're here for.           - Lovely visuals, animation and bossesGameplay - The reason it works, it's new and when you finally get the hang of it. The time flies owning dragons.                  - Amazing quantity of weapons, read the cfg edit on google to toogle on so you can equit any weapon on AI.                  - So many hidden quest, characters, items and formations to unlock.                  - Hire any mercenary's and level them up, and you decide whoever you want to use throughout the game.                  - Re-playable and it rewards you!                  - Can be hard for the new to RPG's if you don't know what you're doing. Google is your friend here.Hours of hours and even if you kill the last boss it's not near complete, this game feels like it could never end.Definently try it out, and give it more than a few hours. PS:PSSS - Turn on Automatic save in options right away, my pc back in the day crashed when I was far in the story. Glad I didn't give up, but it kinda drained my moral. Funny thing I got a better start from doing it over, and better combat/spells.

content:
2015
												I'll start with the cons: the protagonist is a whiny kid who I couldn't care less about, the characters are almost all cookie-cutter with almost every action they make utterly predictable and the story unfolds so slowly and makes so little sense that I stopped even trying to follow it and just fell into a "so they want me to go here" mentality...Now having said that the pros:The gameplay is excellent and it's a lot of fun. The reason I had so much trouble following the story is that I'd spend a 1/2 hour on a story mission and then 20 hours doing other things. Training skills and upgrading weapons is an almost never ending task and you can lose yourself in it... I eventually had to tell myself enough and force myself to carry on the storyline. Equally you can lose yourself in the intricacies of so many aspects of the game. Weapon choice, formation, which characters to take and what squads to put them in: there are so many options with so many equally good choices. Many games claim to give you the option of how to win, this one really delivers.My view of this game is that the developers put great effort into the innovative gameplay and astonishing depth of detail of the mechanics but almost none into the characters themselves or the story which impressively manages to be both utterly boring and overcomplicated/confusing. It has the feel of a game developed by a statistician: all numbers and no heart. That said it's still a lot of fun and I recommend it to anyone who enjoys RPGs but, if you are like me, you'll probably find yourself getting angry that this is only a 'good' game and not the 'great' game it could so easily have been.[rant]Now to let off some steam:David- the protagonist that never was.  He's cool, already got good reasons to be fighting without needing to insert cookie-cutter motivations and would have been an original choice: the little-boy-lost character is common, the subornative-lord fighting to regain his kingdon's independence from a benevolent neighbour is totally unique in my experience.Torgal- the 'tall dark stranger'. His story also happens to be far more interesting then anything Rush gets up to... Khrynia- OMG WTF. Anyone who doesn't know what that means will hate her with a passion, anyone who knows but doesn't speak them as acronyms will hate her with a passion and anyone who does will rightly feel that she's an insult taking the ♥♥♥♥ out of them and will hate her with a passion. Which is a shame because, other then being the irritational equal of young Anakin Skywalker, she's actually quite interesting.Bristly Dragon Mane- proof that someone is a serious sadist. I had about 6 characters need this component and each one needed 6-12 of them... so that's about 50 BDMs in total. At 15% drop chance that means I would need to defeat 333 dragons. Even reloading before a dragon fight until you get the desired result it's going to take a huge amount of time to get what you need. Surely all those respawnable rare monsters dropping rare cores could have been put to a purpose rather then this inane dragon massacre...Accessories- such an enormous choice of accessories, with so many great options all doing slightly different things helping you tailor your 1 character to his goals... the other 17 you control are just gonna do their own thing and occaisonal borrow something you have, if you're lucky. Surely something like Skyrim could have been used: giving allies equipment that they can choose to use if they feel it is beneficial but no, you might have 10 immense accessories sitting doing nothing in your inventory and the chances are you'll only be able to give away 2-3 to your allies.... ARRGGHHBattle Menu- there isn't one... there is no way to exit the game once you start a battle except by finishing it, either by winning or losing. If you are called away or run out of time you'll need to CTRL+ALT+DELETE, if you've bitten off more then you can chew CTRL+ALT+DELETE, if you've been unlucky and something has happened you can't recover from CTRL+ALT+DELETE.... A really good game doesn't allow you to realize you are going to lose then prolong it for the next 5 minutes as you see all your allies die slowly... and .... inexorably ... bringing... you ... to ... GAME OVERI could keep going but I think that'll do for now[/rant]

content:
2015
												Having just finished it, I can say this game is interesting. Instead of playing with a party, you end up building a small army to fight. It has some peculiar ideas, but not the best execution of them in my opinion, gets very repetitive if you are going for completion. It is still a good jRPG, though far from contender to the best titles out there. I would give it a 3.5/5.Some of the members of your army make no sense being there, and there is very little story when optional team members are concerned. Speaking of story, it makes a bit of a jump here and there, and it is not the greatest at making sense. I did find it enjoyable enough to make me sit through to the end still, though you will need to ignore a plot hole here and there eventually.Most of the content you can see as artificial padding, in the form of the guild tasks, that make you reenter already done dungeons many, many times to find a specific random mob, hated those, and the upgrade system not allowing you to downright give items to your teammates required to upgrade their weapons, so you had to go back and farm them again and again if you care about your teams progression, very annoying. If you don't care, get ready to be pestered about it, because your team asks you for the things they need, over and over and over again, every time you go back to the world map you spend 5 minutes just skipping the dialogs of them asking.The battle system is a nice change from normal jRPGs. You don't directly control your characters, you organize them in units, and then give the unit a general purpose, like "use mystic arts". Then, some of the unit member may use a magic, while others will just regular hit, and it is random who will do what, you can train them in different classes to increase the likelihood they will do what you want, but it is no guarantee. Also, even random battles are challenging, since after each one your party automatically recovers, so there is no excuse to not go all out. The bad side is that the toughest battles end up relying too much on RNG to win.Instead of levels, you have a battle rating, and this is one of the bad things about the game. They give you a general battle rating, and enemies scale according to it, but each one of your characters has a BR as well, and they do not tell you what it is. Some stats are hidden like skill progression, and class changes possible and requirements, and some stuff that appear in old towns that makes you either have to use a guide to know of, or visit everywhere after each story step which is annoying and takes quite a bit.Also you have no control over your teams skills, and sometimes they make the worst possible decisions when leveling up. For instance, I read a lot about this skill called "Cachexia" and how it is essential to kill the optional bosses, and although I had 9 members of my 18 member army capable of learning it, and with magic of it's level, just one of them chose to learn it, and only while doing the dungeon that leads to the final boss. I did grind quite a bit trying to get it, but after failing to do so I ended up having to do everything without it, making it all a lot harder.Overall, I would say get this game during a sale and it is worth it, and give it a play, if only to check it's battle system in the very least, or try to do a quick story playthrough ignoring most sidequests. Don't get too much into micro managing though, or you will need to spend a lot of time on the wiki to try to do things right.

content:
er 19, 2013
												For being pretty much the only actual full console JRPG that got moved onto PC, it's pretty good. It's definitely a love or hate game, but there's a reason for that. It's graphically impressive still for a game that released in 2008/9, offers really fun combat and pre-battle strategy.The Last Remnant is unnecessarily complex. If you attempt to play through this game normally, even reading all hints, tips, and tutorials the game gives you, you will never fully learn or understand the battle system. It's a really cool battle system, in fact my favorite turn-based combat system, incorporating a little (dumb) use of RNG. This should be a fatal flaw of the game design by not telling you all the basics of a JRPG game, but it's fun if you figure it out. I had to reinstall and try this game three times before it clicked.Things you should know before considering playing this game:1: This is the Dwarf Fortress of JRPG's in complexity so you will probably need to read the whole game wiki to FULLY understand and prepare your unions/parties/units2: If you are too low of a battle rank, the game is hard. If you are too high of a battle rank, the game is hard. If you grind, you will get punished. Basically, if you reach a point where a battle is super hard, you've either ♥♥♥♥ed up or you're just not high enough level. The game doesn't give you a clear idea of which it is.  By "grinding", I mean heading to an open field with monsters and clearing it all out just for the sake of grinding. If you're on your way to an objective or on a quest, do fight.3: If you HAVE to battle, DO NOT BATTLE A SINGLE MOB AT A TIME. Battle Rank raises depending on the amount of battles you have, not experience from battles. Try to get every single possible mob in one chained link, then initate the battle. If it's too hard with all those monsters, do one by one anyway.If you didn't read everything I typed above this line of text then do not play this game.TL;DR it's an extremely complex game that offers zero explanation of it's systems because there's no tutorial or visual presentation of information, but the high points are addictive and very fun.

												If Final Fantasy XII was a franchise, then The Last Remnant would be Final Fantasy XII-2. Both produced by Akitoshi Kawazu, TLR shares a lot in common with FF XII: a fantastic medieval fantasy world, grind-heavy battle system which feels very rewarding for those who like it, a bland main character, and totally amazing soundtrack! The Last Remnant suffers from some graphic issues and a forgettable story, but where it shines, it truly shines. For you who like Final Fantasy, or generally a fantasy JRPG with good turn-based battle system, deep tactics and customization, and great music, The Last Remnant might just be the right game for you.And hey, it's pretty cheap now.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
7, 2016
												Wow, what an adventure.To get to the nitty gritty, let me focus on a couple of parts of the game: the battle system, the story, and the ending.The battle system:The battle system of this game is unique and definitely improved the game in my opinion. If you are unfamiliar, you have multiple squads under your commands that attack in sets. If you've played Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic, it is somewhat similar, but much more smoothly executed and on a much grander scale. The battles feel huge in certain cases, and it really adds to the experience in that it makes it feel like you're fighting a war right off the bat, rather than just skirmishes.10/10The story: The story was very engaging, and this characteristic is largely why I prefer RPGs to other types of games. Though it has a couple of predictable plot twists, the world is immersive. The side quests definitely add to the story and add to the immersive-ness of the world, as well as providing tangible advantages such as recruiting valuable characters and the acquisition of powerful weapons. There were a couple of problems, such as the ending feeling rushed, but I'll get into that in the next section.8/10The ending: The ending was absolutely the worst part of the game. I think it's odd to feature the ending as a part of the review, but I felt very strongly about it. This game can be split up into two fairly individual parts (to the point where one could have actually been a sequel). The second half of the game felt rushed compared to the first part. I felt like, where the story had a comfortable and reasonable progression in the first half, I felt like I was barrelling through the story when I went at the same pace for the second. At endgame, the game really just kind of feels like it skids to an emergency halt. The final boss is scaled in difficulty to the progression of your character, which is nice, and the final boss did take me a few tries, but when I did actually beat it, I was for some reason a little disappointed. The ending cutscenes did give me a feeling that I was finished, but the satisfaction wasn't really there. For the reasons that the ending was sort of abrupt, but well written, I give the ending a6/10Overall:I highly recommend this game, overall 8/10

content:
, 2014
												My reason for not recommending this game is technical - It is a bad port. It is not optimized for the PC.I have been to forums, trying out every suggestion to make the video and graphics better, as it should be since this is a 2009 game and my rig, though not the most powerful, still can hold its own.I have tried every graphics setting all the way down to low and none. I've lowered resolution to 1280x720. It improves performance, but only slightly.Slightly.My gosh, I mean seriously, there have been guys in forums stating that their rigs can run CRYSIS 1 and 2 fully maximized everything, and this game makes their gaming rigs cry uncle.What gives?I have one last trick that I can try. I will install this in my SSD hard drive. Hopefully it will make this game run silky smooth. But I'm not confident, as I have played another port (ENSLAVED: Odyssey to the West) in my SSD and I had cutscene loading problems.I guess its true, what they say - ports from consoles suck eggs 95% of the time.I want to like this game. Seriously, I do. I'm even willing to do the research in the wikis necessary to be able to play it the smart way. Its just dumbed down by technical reasons. Too bad.UPDATE: Keep ALL video and graphics settings to DEFAULT VALUES and it should run silky smooth. With this info, I change my recommendation from NOT Recommended to Recommended.Wooohooo!!!! Time to enjoy some Japanese RPG!

content:
, 2016
												The Last Remnant has been one of the few games which I can replay and experience it differently even though the story is the same (bar one set side quest options). I originally played this game on the Xbox 360 so I'm used to the game mechanics, however I have to play with a controller on this steam version as the controls for the keyboard are difficult in comparison as the buttons aren't as straight-forward. The game doesn't have steam achievements.Game: Overall, the plot of the game is pretty straight forward as you get reminded or can talk to NPCs to tell you what you need to do. After completing several story points, you are almost able to fully explore the world from near the start of the story, adventuring through the different areas and unlocking other towns. Some are mandatory for the story to progress but others are optional. Side quests pop up after most story events, so revisiting towns and cities are a must if you want to complete them all.Battle System:This is a hit or miss for everyone. I know plenty of people who dislike the battle system due to controlling a union of people but not being able to control each and every single unit. At first it is confusing as not many games use this style but after getting to grips with it, it is extremely useful and conserves time. Since it's a turn based game, imputting the attacks takes long enough to decide as unions so it's literally a godsend that we don't control each character exactly. The camera angles of the fighting keeps you involved in the fight as it follows those whose turn it is attacking/supporting/on standby. Another way this game involves you is by using a critical trigger. It requires you to press the button when the ring encloses over it. By doing so, not only do you bump up your allies in the turn system but also improve the critical chance of your attacks as well as a chance of synergising the last allies attack to a better one if you have enough Action Points(AP). Battles have frontal attacks (deadlocks), side attacks (flanks) and rear assaults which can give your parties edge in a battle but enemies also have the ability to do the same.Unions:You can choose who you want in your party by either completing their missions and buy there services in the guild or talking to one of the soldiers in Athlum (when you are given permission). Certain characters are required for side quests to appear. Unions are made up of a maximum of 5 units. These units/people are chosen by you and can be arranged in different formations to suit their opponents or roles before battle. Different formations have different abilities, strengths and weaknesses so it's fun to play about with what works best. Apart from your character/Rush Sykes, you aren't able to equip other units personally, if you have a weapon and they want it, they'll ask in the map screen if they can take it off your hands. However, they also ask for materials to improve their weapons as well so hunting items down is a good way to increase the strength of your parties. The stats in the game aren't really explained about, neither are class roles but are mostly straightforward apart from their trait stats.Skills: There are multiple arts which can be learnt such as combat, magicks, lotions etc. When learning specific ones, you are able to disable the use of other skills, enabling the one you want to learn more likely to pop up as an option in battle. I've seen a lot of people say the moves all look the same but I disagree with this. Sure, some have the same energy build up but the actual attack performed is different in some way.Visuals & Sound: Originally on the 360, my game was glitchy and laggy most the time. The steam version is much better, there are still glitches at times (like capes spinning about) but the smoothness of the animation at full visual capacity is quite good for a 2008 made game. The detail can take a few seconds to load in though. The voice acting for the game is okay, not the best voice acting but also not the worst. I'm a sucker for Square Enix soundtracks, so the music accompaning the game is quite beautiful and helps set the situation of the game. Within battle, the music can change depending on moral, turns or how close a union is to dying.Other notes: Sovani. Are. Awesome.

content:
22, 2016
												It is a fun game. it has a weird leveling and combat system that i say would turn off people who are more used to more popular RPGs like final fantasy and while it has a nice story, the pacing is a bit off to me and not very fluid. However, the combat system is very unique and can lead to various gameplays and strategies. for a 2009 game, the graphics are very good (but then again, graphics never really matters to me). i never played the xbox version but it has been said that the PC version is a lot better.the bad thing about this game is that they basically don't tell you about anything other than how to fight enemies. it has so much more than that like the upgrading and the leveling system. that leads to people, like me, to resort to outside help like wikis to play them or people just quitting the whole game because they cant figure anything out. if you play blindly and succeed, then i salute you. all in all, i would love to see more of the world and its people and its battle and leveling system expanded. i recommend the game for people who love turn-based RPGs, nice character design, great lore and/or strategy in RPGs (which i would say in a turn-based non-SRPG games are pretty rare). although this is a minor point, i would not recommend the game for people who like to control their party members individually as the battle system can get pretty random unless you set up correctly and for people who cannot stand the phrase "LET'S DO THIS!!!!"7.5/10

												Good game with very poor PC controls. Not only is everything designed for console but the PC controls are very unintuitive and annoying.  But...If you can look past that and the somewhat lacklustre story with too many cut scenes constantly interrupting gameplay. there's a good and deep RPG here. You ednd up commanding a full squad worth of people and the combat mechanics while they initially start out pretty simple get interesting towards the middle game. There's kind of an Elder Scrolls like element to the leveling up process. Your people learn based on what skills you tell them to use so you can make any character into any class (but some will be bad at it due to attributes).  This does have a drawback though of making combat pretty rep[etitive as you will be constantly wanting your troops to practice the same skills over and over to level them up.So yeah I'd put this in the good concept, flawed execution category but it's still worth playing if these kind of RPGs appeal to you at all.

content:
ber 23, 2014
												"7.0/10"+ Rich graphics, memorable symphony music, unique/massive scale fights- Zero character growth, battle commands are random, sidequests are grindfestsA beautiful mechanically sound game that brings in an interesting battle system into an otherwise predictable jrpg plot. The Last Remnant caught my eye from the get-go with its visuals but dulled me back to real life with its  nuanse of storytelling and smaller-than-it-looks worlds. You play as Rush, a stubborn and small-minded individual out to save his sister and the world from destruction (How different!). What saves the narrative is a union-based system that gives you a commander-shouting experience. Rather than control each member, you're giving directions to the union as a whole and letting them decide. It gives the game a unique flair and really, Steam should list "Strategy" as its 2nd or 3rd tag. Without a proper setup; having a healer, disabler, tank, area of effect abilities, you'll be left scratching your head, getting smashed from some of the more formidable story bosses. Thankfully Steam gives you an emulator-esque experience, letting you save at any point in the game as long as you're not presently in a battle. This means you can rewind and plan accordingly. Thin your numbers out with more unions and flank the enemy? Bolster two-three unions for a direct assault? Focus on moral boosting units and leader special abilities? Acquiring more party members is also a treat as you'll be entering towns and recruiting people from various guilds. Getting the better party members requires you to do sidequests... and boy are some of them lengthy. Despite an engaging battle system that keeps you interested, it also has flaws. For one the commands are random. If you want a unit to do something specific, chances are it may not show up. Heal this union? No, sorry, I'll heal this other one. Use our special union ability even though we have enough mana? Maybe next turn. It's discouraging as well as prolongs otherwise 20-30 seconds fights into 2-3 minute charades. Buy:  For the gameplayDon't buy: For the plot

content:
ber 30, 2014
												I absolutely love this game and stand by it. I have put probably about 300-400 hours into this game (not on steam, but mostly on xbox). I bought it on PC because it is a superior version which does allow more specific choices for characters and doesn't punish you for grinding.I Think the battle system and character progression system is great, but not for everybpdy. Your characters will grow depending on the commands you give in battle, the commands you get to choose from in battle are limited, but are always swayed by the choices you have made for that group of characters previously. Instead of having 6 focused characters, which you make specific choices for growth, like in the usual JRPG fare, you have 20 characters and make general choices in combat that indirectly affect the character's growth. It means that all the choices you make will have an impact, so you have to be mindful of what abilities you want a group to have.The battles are both challenging and engaging and unlike other JRPGs I've played. The fact they are large scale is really enjoyable, and you can also speed past them if you'd like. If you really want to enjoy it, you will need to use the wiki for it. There are details which appear as random in this game, but are really a number of complex factors that create a coherent, if unclear, system.The game's content is mostly sidequests and completely optional, and are amongst the most rewarding challenges I have faced in most JRPGs. I always feel like there is more I could do and more progression I could make, creating powerful and interesting combinations of characters.I thik this title is greatly misunderstood and underrated because of the sub-par Xbox release, but is really a unique JRPG gem and will shine through if you have the time and interest.

content:
16, 2014
												I got this game on a whim during a sale, because strictly speaking Square Enix owns at least 1/3 of my soul. I wasn't overly disappointed with TLR. The graphics and controls are pretty top=notch for the game's age, and the difficulty scales well. I did have problems with some tougher bosses based on hiring new units and the way the 'leveling' system works. (Some of my units were woefully underpowered for several fights.) That said, the combat system (controlling several parties) is intriguing, and I'd like to see SE revisit it with a little more traditional RPG leveling system in mind. My only true gripe about this game is something that ALL developers need to take to heart: Skippable. Cutscenes. Even in NG+, the cutscenes are unskippable, and they are LONG. Have popcorn while playing. Overall, I'd give this game a 7/10. Cutscenes notwithstanding, the story can feel a little forced at times, and sometimes hard to follow, and honestly a little boring at points. The combat and gameplay in general are good enough to play through at least once.

content:
ber 14, 2014
												This game was very poorly received upon release; frame rate issues made this game practically unplayable on even the most powerful systems with a serious degradation in visual quality at playable visual settings. This is no longer an issue for many modern GPUs however and we can begin to get the experience originally intended. The last remnant is a fun jrpg, it's not a big departure from square enix's typical offerings and but the combat is functional and the environments and the world is well realised. I had a lot of  fun playing this game, the world is an interesting enough place I was happy to  spend time exploring it and there are plenty of side missions to aid procrastination if you find the main quest moving by a little too quickly.In short, if you like Square Enix's other rpgs you'll probably find yourself enjoying this one; fantastical worlds, winding plot lines and outlandish villains are all in place, together with weapons so massive it'd give even Cloud Strife an inferiority complex.

content:
ber 19, 2014
												Incredible. Absolutely incredible. The Last Remnant is unlike any other RPG i've ever played. Characters grow stronger through battle like most RPGs, but instead of EXP, the individual stats of a character will increase through battle, kind of like a fixed version of FFII. What I really thought was unique in the game was how the party is formed. Units on the battlefield are represented by groups. You assign individual characters to act as one, and then you can assign a formation to that group which can improve a variety of combat skills. I was lucky enough to get this during the Steam Summer Sale for only $2. And let me say, it was the best $2 I have ever, and will spend in my entire life. The only downside is that the game spikes in difficulty sometimes, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but I don't think it's good either. Overall, this game is amazing and deserves a lot more recognition than it already has.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												I feel that TLR does not deserve its 65 metacritic rating. That being said, if you dislike JRPGs, this wont change your mind.The world is nice, the music is fantastic, the characters and story vary from laughable to pretty decent. My only real complaints are as follows;1) Upgrading your characters is wierd. You have no control over what they upgrade, so theyll take items they need after a battle, which sounds cool, but most of the time I would have 30 of the item they suddenly wanted. They should have made NPCs take that junk without having to have a mob drop it when they need it.Due to the wierd way you upgrade your characters, youll have to spend quite a bit of time farming drops, or at least I did. Luckily the combat system is great. The main problem with farming too much is; youre trying to upgrade your character, and the more you level the more difficult mobs become.The characters also harass you until you give them what they want, like a drug addict....you got any of that fly oil Rush.??. *sniff*2) Certain more rare items require magazines, which are dropped from doing guild quests, which arent tracked, so you have to make sure you know what youre doing before you go out. 3)  The max number of units is 18 in a group of 5 (5 per group) WHY in the world they made it 18 characters instead of 25 I cannot fathom. 4) You can miss quests simply because you progressed in the main story, that was just terrible!5) There is a late spike in difficulty. The game goes from a fun challenge to soul crushingly difficult at a certain point. My reviews are always super negative, I enjoyed the game, there are just some odd issues with it. Worth buying! (on sale)

ber 11, 2012
												JRPGs were a holy grail of console gaming in the 8 and 16 bit days. In the 32, there were classics of the genre like Eternal Arcadia, Sakura Wars and Grandia II. Oh, no Final Fantasy? Haven't played once since the Sony monopoly began, which was why this, as one of Square-Enix's cross platform (initially Xbox 360 exclusive) JRPGs was so enticing. I longed to see what they had in store for me. HIronobu Sakaguchi was gone, but I had Lost Odyssey and Blue Dragon, both excellent if not old fashioned games. Sadly, Last Remnant (Last? What is it about JRPGs from this pedigree exhausting the same thesaurus entry?) ran terribly on console. It's release on PC has greatly alleviated these problems, but alas, something about the game leaves me cold. It plays great and has a unique combat and character system, yet ,,, the last remnant of what I onced loved about the genre has dried up. Next stop, Xenoblade and Last Story (there we go again!) for Wii. Here I come.

content:
y 25, 2016
												This game is a beautiful and ambitious tweak to the JRPG formula.  A compelling. interesting story, coupled with above average voice acting and an interesting battle system culminates in one hell of a good time.  It does have its weak points, including the obscure nature of how to find some items required for leveling and a general sense that the game isn't giving you all the stats required to make inform decisions.  However, all in all, The Last Remnant delivers a great experience.Oh, and when it gets a bit sloggy 3/4 the way in?  Just push on through because the rest of the story is one to hold out for.If you loved FF, Tactics, and strategy, I highly recommend the title.  Great game, wish we'd see a sequel.

												My main type of games I love to play are jRPGs with different areas to explore, side quests towards the middle/end of the game, and a variety of equiipment with magical elements to equip and use on bosses, monsters, and the like.Now for this game. At first I was skeptical that I'd like it. I'm not a strategy game type person - this game is not like Risk strategy, more like Final Fantasy Tactis strategy. This game is thrilling, there's a lot of people to meet, levels to get up (Battle Ranks), side quests to do, and different places to go. Granted this isn't a jRPG, but it is a highly fun RPG that is completely underrated. The amount of content and playability will have you guessing what will happen next, what ties are going to be broken (if any), and who you can really trust. If you like looking for a variety of items to craft better equipment or weapons, this has a lot you can craft.

												Very fun, but don't expect to grind your way to victory. Or understand... anything.The combat mechanics, the effect your abilities have, predicting just how much damage certain statistics will cause... who the hell knows? There is such a learning curve, you likely still will be unsure by the end of the game. Charcter suddenly doubles in power, because you forfilled a random hidden requirement for a random hidden skill? Yup, why not.  Been trying to level grind, only to find that it leveled up all the enemies in the game, plus gave them new equipment, while you are still flailing around with a toothpick? Guess you are in for some problems.I find the whole thing insanely fun, and I spend 80% of the game unsure as to what I am doing. I randomly find i've gained new special abilities, which will randomly 1-hit kill somthing one minute, and do virtually nothing the next. Charcters will automatically upgrade their items seemingly for giggles, although there is actually some bizzare formula at work. Apparently.And then there is the insanely un-predictable squad combat system/synergy bonuses. Just roll with it.Stupid fun. Just don't expect to 'get' it.

												The tactics present are quite refreshing from the standard grindy RPG. In fact, you have to carefully plan each battle and NOT grind, otherwise, the enemies will overpower you down the road. The game has a tarnished history from the poor introduction on the Xbox, but, I recommend it as this gem has been polished for the PC!
